				<title>SteveFarrishPhotoArticle</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/?attachment_id=2197</link>

				<title>Smiling Girls</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/content_block/mission-history/attachment/thomas-kinkade-in-guatemala-negs-returned-to-jon-warren-32002/</link>

		<wp:post_name>thomas-kinkade-in-guatemala-negs-returned-to-jon-warren-32002</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>inherit</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>2535</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>attachment</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:attachment_url>http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/SmilingTwoInigGirls2.jpg</wp:attachment_url>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attached_file</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2011/06/SmilingTwoInigGirls2.jpg]]></wp:meta_value>

		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_attachment_metadata</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:6:{s:5:"width";s:3:"988";s:6:"height";s:3:"636";s:14:"hwstring_small";s:23:"height='82' width='128'";s:4:"file";s:32:"2011/06/SmilingTwoInigGirls2.jpg";s:5:"sizes";a:7:{s:9:"thumbnail";a:3:{s:4:"file";s:32:"SmilingTwoInigGirls2-270x150.jpg";s:5:"width";s:3:"270";s:6:"height";s:3:"150";}s:6:"medium";a:3:{s:4:"file";s:32:"SmilingTwoInigGirls2-300x193.jpg";s:5:"width";s:3:"300";s:6:"height";s:3:"193";}s:5:"large";a:3:{s:4:"file";s:32:"SmilingTwoInigGirls2-640x411.jpg";s:5:"width";s:3:"640";s:6:"height";s:3:"411";}s:14:"post-thumbnail";a:3:{s:4:"file";s:32:"SmilingTwoInigGirls2-233x150.jpg";s:5:"width";s:3:"233";s:6:"height";s:3:"150";}s:11:"banner-wide";a:3:{s:4:"file";s:32:"SmilingTwoInigGirls2-940x150.jpg";s:5:"width";s:3:"940";s:6:"height";s:3:"150";}s:11:"slider-item";a:3:{s:4:"file";s:32:"SmilingTwoInigGirls2-520x260.jpg";s:5:"width";s:3:"520";s:6:"height";s:3:"260";}s:6:"banner";a:3:{s:4:"file";s:31:"SmilingTwoInigGirls2-660x80.jpg";s:5:"width";s:3:"660";s:6:"height";s:2:"80";}}s:10:"image_meta";a:10:{s:8:"aperture";s:1:"0";s:6:"credit";s:23:"Jon Warren/World Vision";s:6:"camera";s:0:"";s:7:"caption";s:1012:"'Thomas Kinkade In Guatemala'  - NEGS RETURNED TO JON WARREN 3/2002 
Two of Thomas Kinkade's sponsored children.  
Thomas Kinkade trademarked as the 'Painter of Light' is widely regarded as America's most popular living artist.  His radiant renditions of country gardens, lighthouses and small town streets are reproduced on canvas lithographs, prints, books, posters, calendars, cards, collector plates, figurines, and a line of home furnishings.  A committed Christian, Thomas describes his paintings as 'quiet messengers affirming the basic values of home and family, faith in God, and the luminous beauty of nature.'  A father of four daughters, Thomas says God challenged him to advocate for the world's poorest children through becoming a World Vision spokesman.  Thomas, his wife, Nanette, and his 11-year-old daughter, traveled to Guatemala in March of 1999 to Visit World Vision projects and to meet two of the four children the Kinkade family sponsors.      
Latin America        
color
horizontal";s:17:"created_timestamp";s:1:"0";s:9:"copyright";s:0:"";s:12:"focal_length";s:1:"0";s:3:"iso";s:1:"0";s:13:"shutter_speed";s:1:"0";s:5:"title";s:67:"'Thomas Kinkade In Guatemala'  - NEGS RETURNED TO JON WARREN 3/2002";}}]]></wp:meta_value>

				<title>Med pic 1</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/healthcare/attachment/med-pic-1/</link>

				<title>ONIL stove mother and boy</title>

	<item>
				<title>Economic Development</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/content_block/economic-development/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 05 Jan 2011 14:47:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?post_type=content_block&#038;p=884</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3><strong>Testimonies</strong></h3>
<p style="text-align: left;"><strong>Tomás Caal </strong><em>(Chimuis Tanchi, Guatemala)</em></p>

<p style="text-align: left;">"After a work day in the field, we get together with the family and talk about our everyday experiences - good and bad.  We remember how in past years we had a hard..." <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/economic-development/economic-development-santiago-choc/?preview=true&amp;preview_id=931&amp;preview_nonce=36f1eb36ad">read more here </a></p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Home Transformation</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/content_block/home-transformation-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 05 Jan 2011 16:37:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?post_type=content_block&#038;p=962</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3><strong>Testimony</strong></h3>
<p><strong>Doña Diega Gallina (Yeye)</strong> (Guatemala)</p>
<p>[caption id="attachment_964" align="aligncenter" width="216" caption="Before"]<a rel="attachment wp-att-964" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/content_block/home-transformation-2/attachment/donagriegabefore/"><img class="size-medium wp-image-964  " style="margin-top: 1px; margin-bottom: 1px; margin-left: 3px; margin-right: 3px;" title="DonaGriegaBefore" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/DonaGriegaBefore-300x223.jpg" alt="" width="216" height="160" /></a>[/caption]</p>
<p><strong>Yeye</strong> (a widow) is 82 years old and she cooks in the same room where she sleeps.  While in church, she met a lady who told her about the ONIL Griddle Stove and Water Purifier.</p>
<p>[caption id="attachment_965" align="aligncenter" width="216" caption="After"]<a rel="attachment wp-att-965" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/content_block/home-transformation-2/attachment/donagriega/"><img class="size-medium wp-image-965  " title="DonaGriega" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/DonaGriega-300x223.jpg" alt="" width="216" height="160" /></a>[/caption]</p>
<p><strong>Yeye</strong> now owns an ONIL Stove and ONIL Water Purifier and is very happy.  She’s thankful to God for the GLAXO volunteers and HELPS, as their support has allowed her to cook free of indoor smoke and drink clean water.  She expresses her hope that the program will reach more families and change their homes and lives as it has changed hers.</p>
]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Volunteers</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/content_block/volunteers/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Jun 2011 20:04:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?post_type=content_block&#038;p=2145</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>A Tribute to Bill McConnell</h3>
<blockquote><strong>I want to bring you news about a great friend, uncle, team leader, patriot, husband, father, extraordinary business man, a man of great integrity, a man of faith and someone who loved the Americas. </strong></blockquote>
We lost Bill McConnell as 2013 was drawing to a close. <a title="Memorial for Bill McConnell" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2014/01/03/memorial-bill-mcconnell/">Read more...</a>

&nbsp;
<h3>Cammy's Volunteer Experience</h3>
<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2011/05/09/cammy-olsen/"><img class="size-thumbnail wp-image-1893 alignnone" title="CammyPhoto[5]" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/CammyPhoto5-270x150.jpg" width="227" height="126" /></a>
<blockquote><strong>The impact on our Guatemalan friends is beyond words, but the impact these trips have on all of us that volunteer is even more profound.</strong></blockquote>
I was asked to write a short article on my experiences in Guatemala.  As I only work in the operating room and the patients are asleep, I don’t have a lot of stories that I can share about the patients as much as someone in clinic or recovery. What I can tell about are how the trips are coordinated and the impact on the volunteers.

The coordination begins almost after our leadership meeting on Memorial weekend.  Letters and applications are mailed out and... <a title="Cammy's Volunteer Experience" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2011/05/09/cammy-olsen/">read more</a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Donation Options</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/content_block/donation-options/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 09 Aug 2013 14:56:37 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?post_type=content_block&#038;p=3319</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3><img class="size-medium wp-image-1439 alignleft" alt="GetInvolvedStats1" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/GetInvolvedStats12-300x165.jpg" width="300" height="165" /></h3>
<h3></h3>
<h3><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3349" alt="matching" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/matching.jpg" width="300" height="150" /></h3>
<h3>Do you work for a company that matches gifts?</h3>
Let HELPS know if your company has a matching gifts program and we can help make your donation go even farther!

&nbsp;

<a href="https://helps.mylegacyhq.com/"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3350" alt="legacy" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/legacy.jpg" width="300" height="150" /></a>
<h3>Are you interested in making HELPS a part of your estate plan?</h3>
<a href="https://helps.mylegacyhq.com/">Learn about ways</a> you can give back by naming HELPS as a beneficiary in your will or options regarding a more complex trust arrangement -  and how you can eliminate your taxes.

&nbsp;

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3351" alt="check" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/check.jpg" width="300" height="150" />
<h3>Other Ways to Give</h3>
You may also donate by check payable to <em>HELPS International</em>. Please mail to:

HELPS International

Attn: Carolyn Mumphrey
15301 Dallas Parkway
Ste. 200
Dallas, Texas 75001

To make a donation over the phone, please call us at 1-800-41HELPS, or (972)386-2901.
<h3><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/CFC-logo1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-3382" alt="CFC logo" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/CFC-logo1.jpg" width="255" height="173" /></a></h3>
<h3>Are you a Federal government employee or a member of the U.S. Military Forces?</h3>
<div>HELPS International is proud to be a part of the Combined Federal Campaign, the world's largest workplace giving program. Please choose HELPS as your CFC Charity by entering our name on your pledge card!</div>
<div></div>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

				<title>North Texas Giving Day </title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/content_block/north-texas-giving-day/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 10 Sep 2013 19:30:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?post_type=content_block&#038;p=3782</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3><img class="aligncenter  wp-image-3542" alt="guatemala kids" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/guatemala-kids.jpg" width="144" height="105" />Your donation today could help us win the following:</h3>
<ul>
	<li>
<h6>Top 3 nonprofits with the most donors</h6>
</li>
	<li>
<h6>1,929th donation (marking the year The Dallas Foundation was founded)</h6>
</li>
	<li>
<h6>2,013th donation (marking current year)</h6>
</li>
	<li>
<h6>25th, 250th, 2,500th and 25,000th donation (marking 25th anniversary of Harold Simmons Foundation)</h6>
</li>
	<li>
<h6>Golden Tickets: Seventeen randomly pulled $1,000 prizes awarded hourly for nonprofits that received donations during that hour</h6>
</li>
	<li>
<h6>Happy Hour Prizes: Highest number of donors between 4pm-7pm</h6>
</li>
	<li>
<h6>Best Non-Profit/Business Partnership: The Non-profit with the best partnership with a for‐profit business to raise money</h6>
</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Tribute to Bill McConnell</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/content_block/tribute-bill-mcconnell/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Jan 2014 16:07:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?post_type=content_block&#038;p=4075</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>
<h4>So in this New Year, may we celebrate Bill and his new life and ours.  May we resolve to live to his standards of life and may God bless us all in 2014.</h4>
</blockquote>
<h4>I want to bring you news about a great friend, uncle, team leader, patriot, husband, father, extraordinary business man, a man of great integrity, a man of faith and someone who loved the Americas.  We lost Bill McConnell as 2013 was drawing to a close.  Bill was born in 1924 and lived most of his life in Jackson, Michigan.  Bill represented that great generation of World War II and trained pilots to fly most of the airplanes including the famous P-51.  He married Helen Watterson and they had four children, Bill Jr., Chris, Bob and Michelle.  He was an engineer that worked most of his career for Aeroquip and Consumer Power.</h4>
<h4>Many of us met Bill and Helen through the HELPS Medical team experience.  After learning about HELPS and the medical teams, he and Helen volunteered on the Don and Lois O'Neal Dallas Medical Teams in the early 1990's. They worked in the kitchen as Helen is a master cook and baker. One can't forget her acres of pies and her dropping by at breakfast with another huge frosting laden cinnamon bun saying; "It's good for you! Just one more! You will need it today!"</h4>
<h4>Bill met and became close to Don O'Neal's brother Dick and his wife Delores in those Nebaj kitchens.  Both men spoke the same "engineer" language and after their first trip they stayed on with the O'Neal's in Antigua to do a quality assurance analysis of the team kitchen.  Much of what we do and the system employed today in our kitchens and the overall team manual, came from these gentlemen.  Jon Christiansen still remembers the sighs behind him as he peeled potatoes, knowing that according to the schedule he was supposed to be finished 4 minutes earlier.</h4>
<h4>Bill and Helen then asked Lois O'Neal what she thought of them developing a Medical Team from Michigan.  Bill was retired by this time but as all the team leaders in our system, it took huge courage to step out and organize this effort. Bill had no hospital behind him and no real medical co-leader to rely on for recruitment.</h4>
<h4>He did it anyway and pulled in the Weatherwax Foundation and others such as the current medical team leader Jack Wagoner.  He developed a strong cohesive team that has been in operation since 1996.</h4>
<h4>Bill continued until he could not physically make the trip. The year, before his last team, he suffered an aneurism while in Guatemala but was ready to go the next year.  He was the type of man that when he said "Yes", nothing could stop him from fulfilling those three letters.</h4>
<h4>Certainly with his other legacies, Bill's greatest contribution was his family and his impact in Guatemala will go on forever.  His twelve seasons has human and spiritual ripples that have cascaded through those highlands in ways that he is now discovering.</h4>
<h4>I know we will miss him, his laugh, thoughtfulness, intellect, work ethic, humor, and effectiveness. Speaking as his nephew, I have been most blessed and proud to say that William McConnell was my Uncle. God Bless you Bill.  You have joined my father, Dick O'Neal and other HELPS alumni for an effective, humor filled quality assurance meeting.</h4>
<h4>So in this New Year, may we celebrate Bill and his new life and ours.  May we resolve to live to his standards of life and may God bless us all in 2014."</h4>
<h4></h4>
<h4>Sincerely,</h4>
<h4>Steve Miller</h4>
<h4>President, HELPS International</h4>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title></title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2011/06/17/2378/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Jun 2011 22:29:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2378</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The economic state in Latin America can be attributed to many things. Guatemala, for example, is in recovery from a civil war that lasted more than 35 years, leaving the land and its people in a very tough situation. Furthermore, the systems for a sustainable economy have been lost. For people in rural Latin America, corn agriculture is vital to a stable economy. Agriculture Production, when successful, provides its constituents with labor and capital by giving them work and the ability to feed their families with the fruits of their labor. HELPS works towards making corn more than a food source, but a financial asset as a sustainable means for their livelihood. Innovative approach towards Economic Development through Agricultural Projects: micro-loans give families the financial support needed to start a successful operation means for a nutritional livelihood, ensuring a higher quality of life surplus corn becomes money in the pocket creating a foundation for financial independence and sustainability the chance to positively contribute to society while securing a brighter more stable future for families proper training in modern-day farming techniques resulting in increased yields The economic instability within one country can have impacting ripple effects regionally and even globally.  Economic…]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title></title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2011/06/17/2380/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Jun 2011 22:29:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2380</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Latin America is in the midst of an ongoing healthcare crisis. For example, half of Guatemala’s population lives below the poverty line, and nearly 16 percent live in extreme poverty. The limited existing healthcare is largely inaccessible due to financial burdens. Guatemala has 8 million people in its public healthcare system, and the medical budget per person amounts to approximately $55 compared to $3,500 spent per person in the United States.  Moreover, these funds are spent in the major cities of Guatemala, leaving the rural areas with little or no access to healthcare. While the rest of Latin America has varying statistics in this respect, the medical needs are enormous. In response, HELPS is working to extend its healthcare program to other areas throughout Latin America. HELPS International has developed a system of volunteer medical teams to address the healthcare crisis in rural areas of Latin America. These teams are comprised of about 70 members, from physicians and surgeons to nurses and support staff. HELPS’ teams are organized by a system of local chapters throughout the United States. Problems faced by rural Latin Americans: infant and maternal mortality communicable disease sustainability within the existing system lack of financial resource makes…]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Volunteer </title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2011/06/17/2391/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Jun 2011 22:34:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2391</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Whether you want to lend a hand by joining a mission team or assist in the organization of a fundraising event in the United States, there is a volunteer experience available for everyone. Healthcare On average, each medical team is comprised of 100 medical and non-medical volunteers. HELPS provides both immediate medical relief and outreach programs in preventative health. To join a medical team, please fill out this contact form and a team leader will contact you. Construction Through the installation of ONIL Products, such as the ”Plancha” stove and water purifiers, construction teams provide a complete home transformation that has an immediate impact on the life a poor rural family. Construction teams are comprised of people of all ages and talents and the impact you can make on one family is exponential. To join a construction team, please fill out this contact form and a team leader will contact you. Special Events Lend a hand back home, and help coordinate special fundraising events that allow HELPS to continue their work in Central America. With fundraising opportunities run by our three branch offices and by our Medical/Construction Teams, there is truly an opportunity for everybody. To find out more about how you can help, contact Amanda…]]></content:encoded>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Welcome to HELPS International.  We are an organization that believes we can make a difference in people’s lives whether they are a partner, a volunteer, a patient, a farmer or anyone involved in our programs. Not only do we believe that we can, but we have been actively helping change people’s lives in Guatemala since 1984 and now in Mexico, El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua.   The programs discussed are not “on a napkin at dinner”, nor in a futuristic study, nor in a speech, but are real time, right now, as you read this letter. Please browse through our website and find out more about our market based, sustainable, prosperity producing programs of integrated poverty reduction. Learn how you can get involved directly or indirectly with HELPS through volunteering on a mission team, supporting us financially, becoming a corporate partner, or supporting us with your prayers and ideas.  We are an organization that believes that the programs outlined in this website can help transform an individual, community and country. We need your help to do this. Become a part of an organization made up of people that have left their “couch” and will never return. Those who have taken action have been forever changed and are…]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title></title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2011/06/17/2400/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 17 Jun 2011 22:38:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2400</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[HELPS International Board of Directors Steve Miller: Mr. Miller is Co-Founder and President of HELPS International and President and CEO of Dillon Gage, Inc. in Addison, Texas.  He joined Paul Townsend in 1982 to initially bring the necessities of food, clothing and blankets to the refugees and needy in the Ixil area of Guatemala during the height of that country’s conflict.  Mr. Miller oversees the development of the HELPS projects and systems into the integrated program of today. Paul Schultz, MD: Dr. Schultz is a plastic surgeon and Medical Director for HELPS International and the St. Cloud Medical Team Leader.  As co-founder of the HELPS Medical Outreach Program and member of the management team since 1988, Dr. Schultz initially assessed the feasibility for highly trained surgical teams from the US to travel to remote areas of Guatemala.  With his supervision, this project has developed into what is now called the largest medical/surgical assistance program in Central America. Richard Grinnell: Mr. Grinnell is the Vice-President and COO of HELPS International. He started with HELPS in 2001 as a Projects Manager for the ONIL Stove Program in Guatemala. Since then, he has worked to further implement the award winning ONIL Products into HELPS’ Programs in Mexico, Guatemala, El Salvador and Nicaragua. Richard also helped with the…]]></content:encoded>

				<title></title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2011/07/11/2666/</link>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[HELPS Education, Proving What Is Possible (Older Education Page Here) At the request of the elders in the Mayan village of Santa Avelina in 1996, HELPS built and manages a private, experimental, primary school in rural Quiché. Together with our local teachers, one-hundred-forty students, and the parent’s committee, HELPS is defining the educational process required to prepare the students to compete in the 21st century. Ethnic and linguistic minorities in countries the world over are struggling to have educational parity and access.  The solution developed from this project will not only affect the burgeoning school-age Mayan children in rural Guatemala but can be applied world-wide.  Volunteer master U.S. educators are dedicated to defining the blueprint in partnership with the community. [caption id="attachment_440" align="alignleft" width="270" caption="The William M. Botnan School, Photo by Tom Smoyer"][/caption] The aftershock from the death and destruction that was heavily inflicted in this area of the highlands during the thirty-six year old conflict is still a tangible reality.   Steve Miller, Founder and President of HELPS, took the photo in the early 1980’s when he first visited the Ixil area where the HELPS school is now located.  As he pointed to the photo hanging in his office, he said to…]]></content:encoded>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[ONIL Solar Desk Lamp Technical specifications for the ONIL Solar Desk Lamp: Material: plastic. Solar Panel: it has a 20-year useful life, charges batteries in 8 hours and provides 6 to 8 hours of light. Moveable Metallic Cable: to set the light to where it is needed. Hanging Hook: allows the lamp to be set in a safe place. Light Emitting Diodes (LED): has 12 intense light emitting diodes. Button: to turn the lamp on and off. The ONIL Desk Lamp is characterized by its ability to work either with solar light, which makes it more economical, or with 3 AA NiCad or NiMH rechargeable standard batteries; there is no need for alkaline batteries.  This innovative system allows you to light for over five hours and recharge more than a hundred times.  It has 12 high-durability and high-lighting bulbs, which allows you to light bigger areas longer. Instructions for the use of the ONIL Solar Desk Lamp: WITH SOLAR ENERGY: Set the panel on a sunny area.  Connect the lamp and a light will turn on, which indicates it is charging.  Leave it connected for 12 hours. Turn it on by pressing the front button.  Perform the same action to…]]></content:encoded>

				<title></title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2012/02/13/2883/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Feb 2012 16:13:11 +0000</pubDate>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[HELPS  International, awarded $17,000 of prize money from the “Green Oscars” – Ashden Awards – for its famous stove design. -     Finalists personally congratulated by His Royal Highness Prince of Wales -     First Lady of Guatemala, Mrs. Wendy de Berger, congratulates Ashden Awards for acknowledging Helps International’s  work in Guatemala. London – 24 June  2004 –The international winners of the prestigious Ashden Awards for Sustainable Energy 2004 were tonight announced at the Ashden annual awards ceremony in London. The Ashden Awards rewarded seven projects from India, Pakistan, Kenya and Guatemala for their inspirational technologies that rely on renewable energy to provide social and economic benefits for local communities as well as protecting the environment. The HELPS International ONIL stove, developed by Don O’Neal, was selected as a finalist among over 100 top sustainable energy projects in the world and received $17,000 for designing a pioneering smoke-free, fuel-efficient stove that cuts the wood required by 70% , eliminates indoor pollution and reduces the risk of burns associated with cooking on open fires. The judges commented: “By bringing this sophisticated fuel-efficient stove into the homes of Guatemala’s rural poor, HELPS is leading the way in the fight against crippling respiratory disease and horrifying burns, while also…]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title></title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2012/02/13/2884/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Feb 2012 16:13:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2884</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The Problem For centuries, many in third world countries, have cooked using open fires on the floors of their “one-room” homes. This traditional method of cooking is the cause of many medical and environmental problems throughout the world.   The following problems were identified by an engineer with HELPS, Don O’Neal, after investigating the cultural and technological issues in the highlands of Guatemala: That the high instances of facial and hand burns were due to children falling into these open fires when they were playing or learning to walk. That excessive smoke inhalation is the leading cause of death in Guatemalan children under the age of 5, according to the World Health Organization.  The deadly gas carbon monoxide was found to be twice the level considered to be dangerous. That inefficient burning of wood for three-stone fires required the women and children to gather huge amounts of wood daily, contributing to Guatemala’s deforestation at a level of 2% per year. The time lost to long treks to get the wood combined with the effect of carrying heavy loads had a detrimental health impact on women and their families. The Solution HELPS International and Don O’Neal developed and has implemented the internationally recognized The ONIL Griddle Stove:  a manufactured, durable stove that minimizes smoke and burns, vents the smoke and reduces wood use by 70%. Today, thousands of families are using the ONIL Stove with the…]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title></title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2012/02/13/2885/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Feb 2012 16:13:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2885</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[ONIL Institutional Stove Technical specifications: Materials used on the ONIL Institutional Stove: Stove Structure, 200-lt barrel. Combustion Chamber, made of fired handcrafted clay. Flap, with 26 cal. aluminized plate. Pot Support, with 3/8” corrugated iron. Chimney, 26” caliber galvanized plate. Pewter Pot, 60-lt (240 glasses) capacity. The ONIL Institutional Stoves were designed taking into account the making of large amounts of food to attend different needs, as is the case in schools in the rural area where the use of firewood is high and out of budget, since it is bought.  The Institutional Stove uses the latest technology in terms of combustion, since it uses 100% of the generated energy reducing the use of firewood up to 80% compared to an open fire.  Security characteristics have been included in the design, such as: a full chimney system to extract all contamination of the area where it is used, the guarding of the combustion chamber which protects it from being harmed by the firewood and allows oxygen in to make the required combustion more efficient, and a chimney protection to prevent burns.  Practical characteristics have also been included, such as: easy transportation and installation, simple maintenance and easy movement. Dimensions of…]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2885</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-02-13 08:13:11</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-02-13 16:13:11</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		<wp:post_name>2885</wp:post_name>

	<item>
				<title></title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2012/02/13/2886/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Feb 2012 16:13:11 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2886</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[ONIL Nixtamal Stove Technical specifications: Materials used on the ONIL Nixtamal Stove: Stove Structure, half a 200-lt barrel. Combustion Chamber, made of fired handcrafted clay. Flap, with 26 cal. aluminized plate. Pot Support, with 3/8” corrugated iron. The ONIL Nixtamal Stoves are designed taking into account the needs of women to prepare foods in rural homes using the latest technology in terms of combustion and utilization of generated heat.  The Nixtamal Stove was created to avoid the use of open fires when high capacity pots are used, as is the case when Nixtamal is prepared or stews for large families are made.  The design uses a combustion chamber to save on firewood and the stove base is completely isolated to avoid burns on contact.  Since it doesn’t have a chimney, the use of these stoves is recommended in well ventilated rooms.  Practical characteristics have also been included, such as: easy transportation and installation, simple maintenance and easy movement. The dimensions of the ONIL Nixtamal Stove are the following: Diameter: 23”                          Height: 17” Benefits of the ONIL Nixtamal Stove: Heating time, starting with a cold stove and boiling 6 lts of water in a 12-lt pot, is only 22 minutes.…]]></content:encoded>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Basic home improvements and more efficient kitchens can transform a family’s life into a smoke free environment, drinking purified water, reducing the amount of firewood used by 70% and dramatically improving their quality of life.  The following is a list of all of the ONIL Products: Griddle Stove Nixtamal Stove Water Purifier Institutional Stove (in schools and institutions) Retained Heat Cooker Solar Desk Lamp Rechargeable Water Resistant Flashlight [caption id="attachment_409" align="aligncenter" width="78" caption="Griddle Stove"][/caption] Technical Sheet [caption id="attachment_407" align="aligncenter" width="86" caption="Nixtamal Stove"][/caption] Technical Sheet [caption id="attachment_404" align="aligncenter" width="86" caption="Solar Desk Lamp"][/caption] Technical Sheet   [caption id="attachment_411" align="alignright" width="86" caption="Water Filter"][/caption]   [caption id="attachment_406" align="aligncenter" width="79" caption="Institutional Stove"][/caption] Technical Sheet [caption id="attachment_408" align="aligncenter" width="86" caption="Retained Heat Cooker"][/caption]   [caption id="attachment_405" align="aligncenter" width="78" caption="Rechargeable Water Resistant Flashlight"][/caption] Technical Sheet]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title></title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2012/02/13/2893/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Feb 2012 16:13:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2893</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[HELPS designed its Gravity Water Filter as a practical solution to the need for safe drinking water, using quality components at a very accessible price. The water filter provides 10 gallons of safe drinking water in 24 hours.  It is simple to use and the Initial setup time is about 15 minutes. Water purification: Safe drinking water is often taken for granted, and provision in rural areas is seldom made for a safe backup supply.  Bacteria free water is an absolute necessity and experts advise that a person needs one gallon per day in an emergency.  During emergency situations, a piped water supply may not be available. Even though one can survive weeks without food, one can only survive three days without safe drinking water. Water from rivers, streams, ponds, or rainwater may be the only sources of water for some rural villages in Guatemala and other parts Latin America.  The water may be murky, with an unpleasant odor and taste, and it could be a source of disease,  since 60% of all diseases are water-borne.  Even clear and apparently fresh water may be polluted with microspic disease-causing pathogens, and children are especially vulnerable. The HELPS Gravity Water Filter is specifically designed to micro-filter a supply of safe drinking water  using a simple two container system.  A person simply pours the water into the top container where it then filters…]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title></title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2012/02/13/2924/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Feb 2012 17:01:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2924</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Theory of Operation Several factors working together make the HELPS stove efficient, safe and convenient. The cast concrete stove body is molded in fiberglass molds, providing a fast low cost way of producing a long lasting, low cost stove body.  The body, however only provides structure for the stove.  Two main factors make the stove fast heating and fuel efficient.Complete combustion In order for all energy in the wood to be converted to hot gases, it must be completely burned including the oil vapor that normally would be emitted as smoke.  Containing the fire in a insulated combustion chamber allows the fire to burn hot enough to consume the oil vapor.  Smoke is wasted fuel.  It is also a health hazard both inside and outside the house. The photo at the top shows a stove housing with the clay combustion chamber but without the insulation. In the middle is a photo after the insulation has been added.  Note the square opening of the combustion chamber and also the rectangular slot along the back that collects the hot gases and vents them to the outside through the chimney. As the gases pass back from the combustion chamber to the collection slot, they heat…]]></content:encoded>

				<title></title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2013/06/25/3048/</link>

	<item>
				<title>About Us</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/about-us/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 11 Nov 2010 22:07:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=10</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h4><strong><a title="Mission and History" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/about-us/our-history/">Our Mission</a></strong></h4>
HELPS International’s mission is to provide enduring programs of practical, social and spiritual value to the people in the developing world through a system of partnership and mutual responsibility.
<h4><strong><a title="Our History" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/our-history/">Our History</a></strong></h4>
In the early 1980's, Stephen Miller, an investment banker in Dallas, visited a refugee camp during the thirty-six year civil war in the highlands of Guatemala and joined with Paul Townsend to began the HELPS journey<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/about-us/our-history/"> <span style="color: #3366ff;"><span style="color: #3366ff;">(Read more...)</span></span></a>
<h4><span style="color: #3366ff;"><strong><span style="color: #3366ff;"><a title="Where We Work" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/about-us/where-we-work/">Where we work</a></span></strong></span></h4>
HELPS International started its programs in Guatemala in 1984. Today, HELPS has operations in Guatemala, Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador, and Mexico.
<table width="550" border="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="30%"><a title="A Word From Our President" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/about-us/a-word-from-our-president/"><img class="aligncenter" title="HELPStevereflection3" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/HELPStevereflection3-300x234.jpg" width="180" height="140" /></a></td>
<td width="30%" height="140"><a title="Staff &amp; Leadership" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/about-us/staff/"><img class="aligncenter" title="Staff" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/HELPSStaffReflection3-300x234.jpg" width="180" height="140" /></a></td>
<td width="30%"><a title="Partners" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/about-us/partners/"><img class="aligncenter" title="Alcon Eye Team" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/AlconReflection2PartnerS-300x234.jpg" width="180" height="140" /></a></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Programs</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 11 Nov 2010 22:08:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=15</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[HELPS believes in an integrated approach to poverty reduction. The belief is that the necessary changes start in the home, one family at a time. The Integral Family Development Plan builds a foundation for change, through a collaborative effort of these four programs:
<table width="887" border="0" cellpadding="0">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td width="25%">
<h3><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/education/"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1772" title="EducationReflectionTitle2" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/EducationReflectionTitle2.jpg" width="173" height="139" /></a></h3>
Proving what is possible.</td>
<td width="25%">
<h3><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/overview/"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1774" title="ONILProductsReflectionTitle2" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/ONILProductsReflectionTitle2-300x243.jpg" width="173" height="139" /></a></h3>
Products that change lives.</td>
<td width="25%">
<h3><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/healthcare/"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1773" title="HealthcareReflectionTitle2" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/HealthcareReflectionTitle2-300x243.jpg" width="173" height="139" /></a></h3>
Providing medical relief.</td>
<td width="25%">
<h3><a title="Economic Development Program Page" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/economic-development/" rel="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/economic-development/"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-1771" title="EconDevReflectionTitle2" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/EconDevReflectionTitle2-300x239.jpg" width="173" height="139" /></a></h3>
Money in people's pockets.</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Healthcare</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/healthcare/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 12 Nov 2010 16:12:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="size-medium wp-image-3573 alignleft" alt="medical program" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/medical-program-300x167.jpg" width="300" height="167" />Latin America is in the midst of an ongoing healthcare crisis. For example, half of Guatemala’s population lives below the poverty line, and nearly 16 percent live in extreme poverty. The limited existing healthcare is largely inaccessible due to financial burdens. Guatemala has 8 million people in its public healthcare system, and the medical budget per person amounts to approximately $55 compared to $3,500 spent per person in the United States.  Moreover, these funds are spent in the major cities of Guatemala, leaving the rural areas with little or no access to healthcare. While the rest of Latin America has varying statistics in this respect, the medical needs are enormous. In response, HELPS International has developed a system of volunteer medical teams to address the healthcare crisis in rural areas of Latin America. These teams are comprised of about 70 members, from physicians and surgeons to nurses and support staff. HELPS’ teams are organized by a system of local chapters throughout the United States.
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><strong><a title="HELPS Medical Teams" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/healthcare/overview/"><em>Learn about our current medical teams here.</em> </a></strong></h4>
<strong><em><img class="size-medium wp-image-3574 alignright" alt="healthcare 2" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/healthcare-2-300x184.jpg" width="300" height="184" />Problems faced by rural Latin Americans:</em></strong>
<ul>
	<li>infant and maternal mortality</li>
	<li>communicable disease</li>
	<li>sustainability within the existing system</li>
	<li>lack of financial resource makes receiving healthcare unattainable for most</li>
</ul>
Together, physicians from the United States and Latin America staff these facilities and provide comprehensive care.  HELPS medical teams are fully equipped to provide, as close as possible, US standard healthcare and after years of service have begun to better understand the healthcare crisis. In addition to providing direct healthcare, HELPS implements further programs in an effort to secure better long-term health.

<strong><em><img class="size-medium wp-image-3576 alignleft" alt="Medical girl w glasses" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Medical-girl-w-glasses-200x300.jpg" width="200" height="300" />Program History</em></strong>

HELPS’ Medical Program began in 1988 when an eight member US plastic surgery team traveled to a small village in the northern highlands of Guatemala. With unstaffed hospitals already situated in remote areas of the Guatemalan highlands, HELPS worked in cooperation with the Guatemalan government to make use of these facilities. The HELPS medical teams quickly gained momentum, spreading through Guatemala and covering a much larger area of the country. Since then, the programs have grown immensely, gaining the support needed to move beyond the walls of the hospitals. Many of our doctors have continued to support HELPS medical teams for decades, continuing to embrace the people and culture of Latin America and to alleviate the tension of their healthcare situation.

&nbsp;

<em><strong>Program Achievements:</strong></em>
<ul>
	<li>Since 1988, over 190 Volunteer Medical/Surgical Teams have worked in the Guatemalan Highlands</li>
	<li>Over 215,000 patients have been attended to  (including outreach to nearby communities)</li>
	<li>Over 16,000 general, plastics, OB-GYN, eyes, and dental surgeries have been performed</li>
	<li>Over $190,000,000 in direct medical aid to Guatemala has been donated through HELPS mission teams</li>
</ul>
<em><strong><img class="size-medium wp-image-3581 alignright" alt="Med pic 1" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Med-pic-1-300x200.jpg" width="300" height="200" />The Comadrona Project:</strong></em>

According to the World Health Organization's 2009 Statistics, 75% of deliveries in Guatemala are attended by midwives. HELPS is working with professional midwives and gynecologists to educate people of rural areas on proper technique:
<ul>
	<li>instrument sterilization</li>
	<li>infant resuscitation</li>
	<li>Prevention/control of hemorrhage<img class="size-medium wp-image-3580 alignright" alt="volunteers healthcare" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/volunteers-healthcare-300x176.jpg" width="300" height="176" /></li>
</ul>
<strong><em>Developing basic knowledge of Preventative Health in the community through educational visits:</em></strong>
<ul>
	<li>personal and family hygiene</li>
	<li>nutrition</li>
	<li>environmental awareness</li>
	<li>waste management</li>
	<li>family planning</li>
</ul>
<img class="alignleft  wp-image-3585" alt="doctor and patient" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/doctor-and-patient-300x229.jpg" width="240" height="183" />

<strong><em>How to Volunteer for a Medical Team</em></strong>

If you would like to go on a medical trip or form your own medical team, <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/">click here to fill out an application</a>. If you would like to speak with us please call (972)386-2901 or email <a href="mailto:info@helpsinternational.org">info@helpsinternational.org</a>. To see our HELPS Teams in action please <a title="News/Media" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/news-and-media/">watch our healthcare videos</a>.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>ONIL Products </title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 24 Nov 2010 15:43:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1 style="text-align: center;"><img class=" wp-image-3950 alignright" alt="Wood Burning Open Fire" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Open-Fire-Stove-in-Home-300x284.jpg" width="270" height="256" /></h1>
<h1 style="text-align: center;">The Challenge</h1>
In the late 1980′s, HELPS International’s medical teams reported an alarming number of children being treated for burns and numerous respiratory problems. Engineer Don O’Neal, a medical team leader with HELPS, investigated and found that the problem was the method of cooking used by the indigenous Mayan women in their homes. This centuries’ old tradition of cooking meals within the home using an open fire pit on the dirt floor known as a “three-stone fire”, had no ventilation, causing families to inhale dangerous fumes causing Acute Respiratory Infections (ARI). More specifically, Mr. O’Neal found:
<ul>
	<li>The high instances of facial and hand burns were due to children falling into these open fires when they were playing or learning to walk.</li>
	<li>According to the World Health Organization, excessive smoke inhalation is the leading cause of death in Guatemalan children under the age of 5. In a HELPS study, the deadly gas carbon monoxide was found to be fifteen times greater than the EPA base level considered to be dangerous.</li>
	<li>The inefficient burning of wood for three-stone fires required the women and children to gather huge amounts of wood daily (18,000 lbs per family per year), contributing to Guatemala’s deforestation level of 2% per year. The safety issues for women plus the time lost to long treks to gather the wood, combined with the impact of carrying these heavy loads has detrimental health ramifications on women and their families.</li>
	<li>For families that purchased their firewood, this required spending up to 40% of their entire income simply to cook their food.</li>
</ul>
From this start with the ONIL stove, HELPS has developed the ONIL product line that changes the way families live and has become one of the “pillars” of HELPS poverty reduction efforts.  Richard Grinnell, HELPS Vice President, with Don O'Neal and their team has implemented these solutions for families across Central America and Mexico.
<h1 style="text-align: center;"><strong>The Solutions </strong></h1>
<em>Transforming the way a family lives in the home utilizing ONIL Products. Here are two major examples:</em>

<strong><img class=" wp-image-3962 alignleft" alt="ONIL stove mother and boy" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/ONIL-stove-mother-and-boy.jpg" width="286" height="275" />HELPS/ONIL Plancha Stove:</strong>

After consideration of the cultural as well as technological factors surrounding three-stone fires, Don O’Neal developed the “ONIL” Stove, a method of cooking that is compatible with traditional methods.

Today, thousands of rural Mayan families are using the ONIL Stove with the following benefits:
<ul>
	<li>The fire is contained in a clay-fired firebox in an insulated, durable stove that sits off the floor, thus minimizing the risk of burns to small children.</li>
	<li>Vented by a galvanized steel chimney, the stove uses an efficient burning technology, and virtually eliminates smoke and deadly carbon monoxide in the home. Using the ONIL stove means longer life expectancy, safer child development, and more time and energy for families.</li>
	<li>The ONIL stove reduces wood consumption by 70% resulting in a major economic benefit and a better quality of life for families with long-term benefit to the environment.</li>
	<li>Women who use the ONIL stove gained the equivalent of two days a week in time saved from gathering wood, allowing them time for social and economic activities like cultivating a vegetable garden.</li>
</ul>
<strong>HELPS/ONIL Water Filters:<img class="alignright  wp-image-3966" alt="Water Filter" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Water-Filter.jpg" width="277" height="358" /></strong>

HELPS designed its Gravity Water Filter as a practical solution to the need for safe drinking water, using quality components at a very accessible price. The water filter provides 10 gallons of safe drinking water in 24 hours. It is simple to use and the initial setup time is about 15 minutes.

Safe drinking water is often taken for granted, and provision in rural areas is seldom made for a safe backup supply. Bacteria-free water is an absolute necessity and experts advise that a person needs one gallon per day in an emergency. During emergency situations, a piped water supply may not be available. Even though one can survive weeks without food, one can only survive three days without safe drinking water. Water from rivers, streams, ponds, or rainwater may be the only sources of water for some rural villages in Guatemala and other parts of Latin America. The water may be murky, with an unpleasant odor and taste, and it could be a source of disease, since 60% of all diseases are water-borne. Even clear and apparently fresh water may be polluted with microspic disease-causing pathogens, and children are especially vulnerable.

The HELPS Gravity Water Filter is specifically designed to micro-filter a supply of safe drinking water using a simple two container system. A person simply pours the water into the top container where it then filters into the lower container and is purified, providing up to 10 gallons of safe drinking water every 24 hours.

HELPS Gravity Water Filtration systems are manufactured of food grade polyethylene and are hygienic, durable, and easy to clean, with a ceramic element that does not allow bacteria to grow because it is impregnated with environmentally safe silver, and never needs to be sterilized or boiled like other systems.

HELPS’ rigorous in-house and independent testing of its Gravity Walter Filter ensures 100% removal of parasites such as guinea worm and giardia, and 99.99% removal of pathogenic bacteria such as: cholera, e. coli, and shigella. The filtered water measures up to US standards of purification, and provides a safe backup system in times of emergency.
<h3><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>How to Help:</strong></span></h3>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Sponsor an ONIL Product</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Donate a stove, water filter or any other ONIL product (<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/onil-products/onil-product-selection/">see a full list of ONIL's full product selection</a>) and generationally change a family. Each stove and water filter combination costs only <strong>$250</strong> and can change the lives of generations of people. Each stove you donate will be installed in Guatemala by one of our staff or a volunteer mission team. They make excellent gifts, especially for birthdays or holidays! <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/donate/" target="_blank">Click here to make a donation</a>.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><strong>Participate in a Stove Installation Team </strong>
<ul>
	<li>Join an existing HELPS stove team to install these products side by side with Guatemalan families inside their homes. <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/" target="_blank">Click here to fill out a volunteer application</a>.</li>
	<li>Form your own stove team and bring your family, friends, or employees to work together on a project. Call us at 1-800-414-3577 or <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/contact/">fill out our contact form </a>to get started!</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Economic Development</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/economic-development/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 24 Nov 2010 15:47:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-3566" alt="corn 2" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/corn-2.jpg" width="260" height="228" />The economic state of Latin America is varied.  While the region boasts of many resources, opportunities and successes, its poverty rates remain subbornly and unsustainably high.   In fact, Guatemala's poverty rate has increased and the economic and other divisions in the country are becoming more acute.  Divisions of culture, language, access to credit, education and markets and other long term business neccessities have been a historical and current hinderance to the regions development.

Much of the region's population live in the rural areas where infrastructure and developmental tools are lacking or non existant.  The economic system for most rural poor in Central America and Mexico is based on agriculture and more particularly corn production.

Agriculture production, when successful, provides its constituents with sustainable prosperity by giving them the ability to feed their families through their labor.  It has been the historical method used for national development around the world for countries such as the United States.

We at HELPS believe that Central America and Mexico have the ability to develop as did other such countries and there can be a great future for the region providing stability and prospertiy across the varying ethnic and economic lines.  HELPS economic program is centered around creating wealth and stability through the rural poor's primary business interest, agriculture, and specifically in the initial stages, corn production.

Through partnerships with  "small hold farmers" in villages across Guatemala and our corporate partners <strong><a href="http://www.disagro.com/en/crop-nutrition" target="_blank">DISAGRO</a></strong> and <strong><a href="http://www.mosaicco.com/sustainability/food.htm" target="_blank">MOSAIC</a></strong>,<strong> </strong>HELPS has seen audited production levels increase by more than 300% in the villages with "The Algriculture Program".   This program does three things which involve basic building blocks for business:
<ul>
	<li>Provides technology to the small hold farmer through the analyizing of their soils in order to determine the best additives to use for their crops.  In addition, agricultural test plots are run in different areas to determine the correct mineral levels and for the analysis of long term impact products for their current and future utilization.</li>
	<li>The Agriculture Program places<strong> </strong>agricultural technicians in these villages to train the small hold farmer in the proper farming methodologies and for the correct use of agricultural inputs to enhance yield and to protect the environment.</li>
	<li>Provides unsubsidized loans in the forms of agricultural inputs such as fertilizers, all of which is repaid at harvest.  While all the above are critical for long term sustainable success, the unsubsidized loans are what sets The Agriculture Program apart from many agricultural efforts across the world.   The repayment percentage for these loans have been very high turning the hope for such a program into actual verifible reality.<img class="size-medium wp-image-3568 alignright" alt="Corn 1" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Corn-1-300x201.jpg" width="300" height="201" /></li>
</ul>
<strong>Benefits of The Agriculture Program</strong>:
<ul>
	<li>The small hold farmer's family have enough to eat.  This issue is of growing importance as there are more and more reports of starvation for many individuals and entire villages.</li>
	<li>For most, the extra production of corn can be sold in the local market place putting real buying power in the hands of the family.</li>
	<li>Allows for the expansion into other cash crops which pay better and provide a real sustainable income for the family and their communities.</li>
	<li>Because of the lack of historical corn production and the need for the fathers to leave their communities to find outside labor, this increase and sufficient corn production allows the fathers to stay at home which stabilizes the family and helps raise the children.  This stability has community, national and international impact.</li>
</ul>
This agriculture program, along with the other initiatives of HELPS International, are seen by the people of HELPS as absolutely critical to the economic and social futures of these areas and  countries in our hemisphere.  It puts money in the pocket, sustainably and with a future tied to individual responsibility and opportunity.

<strong><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/economic-development/attachment/cornfield/" rel="attachment wp-att-827"><img class="size-medium wp-image-827 alignleft" title="CornField" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/CornField-300x204.jpg" width="300" height="204" /></a></strong>
<blockquote>
<h5><em><strong>We are very happy because we can see the good development of our corn crops, the good color in their leaves and we are confident that this year, with MOSAIC, DISAGRO and HELPS International’s support, we’ll get better production. </strong></em><em><strong>- Tomás Caal</strong></em></h5>
&nbsp;</blockquote>
<strong>History of The Agriculture Program</strong>:

With the support of DISAGRO, the largest fertilizer producer in Central America and Mexico, The Agriculture Program began in 2006.   If DISAGRO had not been willing to pioneer, fund and assist this effort, the ability to impact the small hold farmer in Guatemala would have probably been lost.

The first region where the program was implemented was in Quiché with only 24 families and 3.24 Has; an area where HELPS had been working for many years.  Since then the program has expanded throughout Guatemala with approximately 3,000 farmers now enrolled in the program.

In 2008, MOSAIC, a major corporate global concern  joined the effort.  MOSAIC, the largest potash producer in the world, has contributed time, money and technololgy and has worked hand in hand with DISAGRO and HELPS in creating a program that has national and international impact.

HELPS and her partners believe that we only have a short time to implement this effort across the region as land division will make the land plots so small as it will be impossible to increase corn production to sufficient leverls and for the transfer to better paying crops.

This program is not on a "napkin at dinner", it is real time as this very page is being written.  To sustainably stop hunger and at the same time create real wealth and stability, we will need your to help in order to make this a reality for more than the current group of farmers.

<strong>How to Help</strong>

If you are interested in obtaining our audited results from Deloitte or if you have an interest in becoming a part of the Economic Development Program through The Agriculture Program, please visit our <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/">Get Involved </a>page to learn more.  A HELPS Leader will contact you directly.  If you would like to speak with us directly, please call 800-41-HELPS (800-414-3577) or email <a href="mailto:info@helpsinternational.org">info@helpsinternational.org</a>.]]></content:encoded>

		<dc:creator><![CDATA[admin]]></dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1><span style="font-weight: normal; font-size: 13px;"><a title="Videos" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/news-and-media/videos/"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1619" title="mediavid" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/mediavid.jpg" alt="" width="325" height="300" /></a> <a title="Stories" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/news-and-media/stories/"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-1618" title="mediastor" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/mediastor.jpg" alt="" width="325" height="300" /></a></span></h1>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Plancha Stove</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products/onil-product-selection/onil-griddle-stove/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Dec 2010 15:37:56 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class=" wp-image-4094 alignleft" alt="Winged Stove" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/Great-pic-of-stove-and-cement-flooring-286x300.jpg" width="257" height="270" />

<span style="color: #000000;">For centuries, many people in third world countries have cooked using open fires on the floors of their “one-room” homes. </span>
<blockquote><strong><span style="color: #000000;">This traditional method of cooking is the cause of many medical and environmental problems throughout the world.</span></strong></blockquote>
<span style="color: #000000;">A</span><span style="color: #000000;">fter investigating the cultural and technological issues in the highlands of Guatemala, the following problems were identified by HELPS engineer, Don O’Neal:</span>

&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">High instances of facial and hand burns were due to children falling into the open fires when they were playing or learning to walk.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Excessive smoke inhalation is the leading cause of death in Guatemalan children under the age of 5, according to the World Health Organization.  While finding "normal" levels of twice the levels of carbon monoxide considered to be dangerous, HELPS has found levels to sometimes be up to 25 times these safe levels.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Inefficient burning of wood for three-stone fires required women and children to gather huge amounts of wood daily and is contributing to Guatemala's deforestation at a level of 2% per year.  </span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">The time lost to long treks to get the wood combined with the issue of women's safety and the impact of carrying heavy loads (18,000 lbs. of wood per annum) has had a detrimental health impact on women and their families.</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="color: #000000; text-decoration: underline;"><strong>The Solution</strong></span>

<span style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-345" style="margin-top: 1px; margin-bottom: 1px; margin-left: 3px; margin-right: 3px;" title="Stovegraphic" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Stovegraphic-218x300.jpg" width="131" height="180" /></span>

<span style="color: #000000;"> </span>

<span style="color: #000000;"> </span>

<span style="color: #000000;">HELPS International and Don O’Neal developed and implemented the internationally recognized  ONIL Plancha Stove:  a manufactured, durable stove that minimizes smoke and burns, vents the smoke and reduces wood usage by 70%.</span>

<span style="color: #000000;">HELPS Vice President, Richard Grinnell and his team in the ONIL Products division have developed methods of implementation which equate to a high percentage of "solution acceptance" across the region with the following benefits:</span>
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">The fire is contained in a clay-fired firebox in an insulated, durable concrete and rolled steel stove that sits off the floor, thus minimizing the risk of burns to small children and the time women have to use to guard their children from this risk.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">The ONIL  stove uses an efficient burning technology which virtually eliminates smoke and deadly carbon monoxide in the home.   However HELPS recognizes that while efficient burning is important, the remaining smoke and particulates are vented by a galvanized steel chimney.  Using the ONIL stove means longer life expectancy, safer child development, and more time and energy for families.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">The ONIL stove reduces wood consumption by 70%, resulting in  long-term benefits to the environment and a better quality of life for families.  It is estimated that one stove saves one commercial tree every month for the life of the stove, with stoves still operational since 2002.  In addition, if a family purchases their wood at $25 dollars a month, the ONIL stove saves $200 a year for families who make a total of $600 per annum.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Women who use the ONIL stove gained the equivalent of two days a week in time saved from gathering wood.  Women are main agents of change both economically and socially and this saved time allows for the type of involvement that can change a nation.</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><span style="color: #000000; text-decoration: underline;"><strong>How to Help:</strong></span></h3>
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>Sponsor a Stove</strong></span>
<ul>
	<li>Donate a stove, water filter or any other ONIL product (<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/onil-products/onil-product-selection/">see a full list of ONIL's full product selection</a>) and generationally change a family. Each stove and water filter combination costs only <span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>$250</strong> </span>and can change the lives of generations of people. Each stove you donate will be installed in Guatemala by one of our staff or a volunteer mission team. They make excellent gifts, especially for birthdays or holidays! <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/donate/" target="_blank">Click here to make a donation</a>.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><strong>Participate in a Stove Installation Team </strong></span>
<ul>
	<li>Join an existing HELPS stove team to install these products side by side with Guatemalan families inside their homes. <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/" target="_blank">Click here to fill out a volunteer application</a>.</li>
	<li>Form your own stove team and bring your family, friends, or employees to work together on a project. Call us at 1-800-414-3577 or <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/contact/">fill out our contact form </a>to get started!</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_date>2010-12-13 07:37:56</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2010-12-13 15:37:56</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>onil-griddle-stove</wp:post_name>

				<title>Partner</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/partner/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 14 Dec 2010 03:11:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: center;">HELPS is honored to have business partners who represent the hopes &amp; dreams of their owners &amp; employees. If your company is interested in integrating your business strategy with social value, HELPS would like to work together to make a lasting impact within the communities we serve. To partner with HELPS, please contact Michelle Hollaender at 972.386.4294 or <a href="mailto:mhollaender@dillongage.com">mhollaender@dillongage.com</a>.<b></b></p>

	<item>
				<title>Institutional Stove</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products/onil-product-selection/onil-institutional-stove/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 15 Dec 2010 03:08:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In rural Guatemalan schools, open cooking fires are commonly used within rural school buildings.  These open indoor fires produces the same toxins and particulates that are found in the open cooking fires that are used within the rural homes.

HELPS created the <strong>ONIL Institutional Stove </strong>to address this issue within schools and other institutions.  This indoor stove allows for cooking large quantities of food in large capacity pots while venting the cooking smoke to the outside.

<strong><img class="size-medium wp-image-406 alignleft" title="InstitutionalStoveGraphicSmall" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/InstitutionalStoveGraphicSmall-218x300.jpg" width="218" height="300" />
</strong>The <strong>Institutional Stove</strong> was designed using the latest technology in terms of combustion, since it uses 100% of the generated energy reducing the use of firewood up to 80% compared to an open fire.  Security characteristics have been included in the design, such as: a full chimney system to extract all contamination of the area where it is used, the guarding of the combustion chamber which protects it from being harmed by the firewood and allows oxygen in to make the required combustion more efficient, and a chimney protection to prevent burns.  Practical characteristics have also been included, such as: easy transportation and installation, simple maintenance and easy movement.

<strong>Dimensions of the Institutional Stoves<em>:</em></strong>

Diameter: 23”                          Height: 25”

<strong>Benefits of the Institutional Stoves<em>:</em></strong>
<ul>
	<li>Heating time, for the boiling of 40 lts of water in a pewter pot, is only 50 minutes.</li>
	<li>Reduction of emission of CO and carbon particles in the home environment compared to an open fire: CO from 408 ppm to 114 ppm.</li>
	<li>80% reduction in the use of firewood compared to an open fire (an average of 38 households monitored weighing in kgs the firewood used in 7 days).</li>
	<li>Average installation time of the stove, which can be immediately used, is 20 minutes.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Durability of the ONIL Institutional Stove<em>:</em></strong>

If the stove is used and maintained properly, a minimum of 10 years is expected of its structure.  The flap must be changed depending of its wearing, which varies in time depending on maintenance effectiveness and frequency as well as the type of firewood used.
<h3><strong>How to Help:</strong></h3>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Sponsor an ONIL Product</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Donate a stove, water filter or any other ONIL product (<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/onil-products/onil-product-selection/">see a full list of ONIL's full product selection</a>) and generationally change a family. Each stove and water filter combination costs only <strong>$250</strong> and can change the lives of generations of people. Each stove you donate will be installed in Guatemala by one of our staff or a volunteer mission team. They make excellent gifts, especially for birthdays or holidays! <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/donate/" target="_blank">Click here to make a donation</a>.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><strong>Participate in a Stove Installation Team </strong>
<ul>
	<li>Join an existing HELPS stove team to install these products side by side with Guatemalan families inside their homes. <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/" target="_blank">Click here to fill out a volunteer application</a>.</li>
	<li>Form your own stove team and bring your family, friends, or employees to work together on a project. Call us at 1-800-414-3577 or <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/contact/">fill out our contact form </a>to get started!</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
