	<item>
				<title>Water Filter</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products/onil-product-selection/onil-water-filte/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 15 Dec 2010 04:01:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Sixty percent of all disease is water borne and the lack of clean drinking water impacts all levels of society.  HELPS has designed its Gravity Water Filter as a practical solution to the need for safe drinking water, using quality components at a very accessible price. The water filter provides 10 gallons of safe drinking water in 24 hours.  It is simple to use and the Initial setup time is about 15 minutes.

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products-2/onil-water-filte/attachment/waterpurifier/" rel="attachment wp-att-560"><img class="wp-image-560 alignleft" title="WaterPurifier" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/WaterPurifier-296x300.png" width="237" height="240" /></a>Safe drinking water is very often not available with no provision in rural areas for a safe backup supply.  Bacteria and pathagen free water is an absolute necessity for good health with experts advising that a person needs one gallon of clean water per day.  During emergency situations, the <strong>Gravity Water Filter </strong>is also critical to survival as a piped water supply may not be available. Even though one can survive weeks without food, one can only survive three days without safe drinking water.  Most rural people draw water from rivers, streams, ponds, or rainwater, which may be the only sources of water for some rural villages in Guatemala and other parts of Latin America. Water may be murky, with an unpleasant odor and taste and can easily be a source for disease and infection.  Even clear and apparently fresh water may be polluted with microscopic disease-causing pathogens, with children being especially vulnerable.  The <strong>Gravity Water Filter </strong>is a<strong> </strong>life saver and life provider.

The <strong>Gravity Water Filter </strong>is specifically designed to micro-filter a supply of safe drinking water using a simple two container system.  A person simply pours the water into the top container where it then filters into the lower container, providing up to 10 gallons of safe, filtered drinking water every 24 hours.

The <strong>Gravity Water Filter </strong>systems are manufactured of food grade polyethylene  and are hygienic, durable, and easy to clean, with a ceramic element that does not allow bacteria to grow  because it is impregnated with environmentally safe silver, and never needs to be sterilized or boiled like other systems.

<strong>Performance</strong>

HELPS' rigorous in-house and independent testing of its <strong>Gravity Walter Filter </strong>ensures 100% removal of parasites such as guinea worm and giardia, and 99.99% removal of pathogenic bacteria such as:  cholera, e. coli, and  shigella.  The filtered water measures up to US standards of purification, and provides a safe backup system in times of emergency.
<h3><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>How to Help:</strong></span></h3>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Sponsor a Water Filter</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Donate a stove, water filter or any other ONIL product (<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/onil-products/onil-product-selection/">see a full list of ONIL's full product selection</a>) and generationally change a family. Each stove and water filter combination costs only <strong>$250</strong> and can change the lives of generations of people. Each stove you donate will be installed in Guatemala by one of our staff or a volunteer mission team. They make excellent gifts, especially for birthdays or holidays! <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/donate/" target="_blank">Click here to make a donation</a>.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><strong>Participate in a Stove Installation Team </strong>
<ul>
	<li>Join an existing HELPS stove team to install these products side by side with Guatemalan families inside their homes. <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/" target="_blank">Click here to fill out a volunteer application</a>.</li>
	<li>Form your own stove team and bring your family, friends, or employees to work together on a project. Call us at 1-800-414-3577 or <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/contact/">fill out our contact form </a>to get started!</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Jan 2014 16:38:16 +0000</pubDate>

	<item>
				<title>Volunteer Information</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/video/2014/01/13/become-a-volunteer/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Jan 2014 18:06:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>

	<item>
				<title>Nixtamal Stove</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products/onil-product-selection/onil-nixtamal-stove/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 15 Dec 2010 09:36:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[HELPS examination of the issues surrounding open fires within homes in Guatemala involved studying how food is cooked.  In the rural Guatemala home, nixtamal or corn tortilla mix is made in large quantities and it became clear that beyond the indoor <strong>Plancha Stove,</strong> another stove was needed that would be used outside and could handle large quantities of nixtamal or for large family gatherings using large capacity pots.  As a result, the<strong> Nixtamal Stove</strong> was created to address this issue.  Using the same principles found in the  <strong>Plancha Stove</strong>, the  <strong>Nixtamal Stove</strong> has proved to be very effective and efficient in addressing the issues found above.

<strong><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products-2/attachment/nixtamalgraphicsmall/" rel="attachment wp-att-407"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-407" title="nixtamalgraphicSmall" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/nixtamalgraphicSmall-300x265.jpg" width="300" height="265" /></a></strong>

The <strong>ONIL Nixtamal Stove</strong> is designed using the latest technology in terms of combustion and utilization of generated heat.  The design uses a combustion chamber to save on firewood and the stove base is completely isolated to avoid burns on contact.  Since it doesn’t have a chimney, the use of these stoves is recommended to be used outside the home.  Practical characteristics have also been included, such as: easy transportation and installation, simple maintenance and easy movement.

<strong>The dimensions of the ONIL Nixtamal Stove are the following<em>:</em></strong>

Diameter: 23”                          Height: 17”

<strong>Benefits of the ONIL Nixtamal Stove<em>:</em></strong>
<ul>
	<li>Heating time, starting with a cold stove and boiling 6 lts of water in a 12-lt pot, is only 22 minutes.</li>
	<li>Reduction of emission of CO and carbon particles within the home environment compared to an open fire: CO from 408 ppm to 114 ppm.</li>
	<li>80% reduction in the use of firewood compared to an open fire (an average of 38 households monitored weighing in kgs the firewood used in 7 days).</li>
	<li>Average installation time of the stove, which can be immediately used, is 20 minutes.</li>
</ul>
<strong>Durability of the ONIL Nixtamal Stove<em>:</em></strong>

If the stove is used and maintained properly, a minimum of 10 years is expected of its structure.  The flap must be changed periodically according to the amount of wear, and varies in time depending of the type of firewood used.
<h3><strong>How to Help:</strong></h3>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Sponsor an ONIL Product</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Donate a stove, water filter or any other ONIL product (<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/onil-products/onil-product-selection/">see a full list of ONIL's full product selection</a>) and generationally change a family. Each stove and water filter combination costs only <strong>$250</strong> and can change the lives of generations of people. Each stove you donate will be installed in Guatemala by one of our staff or a volunteer mission team. They make excellent gifts, especially for birthdays or holidays! <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/donate/" target="_blank">Click here to make a donation</a>.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><strong>Participate in a Stove Installation Team </strong>
<ul>
	<li>Join an existing HELPS stove team to install these products side by side with Guatemalan families inside their homes. <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/" target="_blank">Click here to fill out a volunteer application</a>.</li>
	<li>Form your own stove team and bring your family, friends, or employees to work together on a project. Call us at 1-800-414-3577 or <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/contact/">fill out our contact form </a>to get started!</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Solar Desk Lamp and Water Resistant Solar Flashlight</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products/onil-product-selection/onil-solar-desk-lamp/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 15 Dec 2010 10:05:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Most Guatemalan rural homes have no access to electricity and with implemented stove solutions removing the light from open cooking fires within the home, the introduction of a dependable, safe and healthy light source was needed.  HELPS engineers recognize that solar technology can address such issues and now offers the <strong>Solar Desk Lamp </strong>and<strong> Water Resistant Solar Flashlight</strong>.  <strong><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products-2/attachment/desklampgraphicsmall/" rel="attachment wp-att-404"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-404" title="DesklampgraphicSmall" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/DesklampgraphicSmall-300x265.jpg" width="300" height="265" /></a>
</strong>

<strong>Technical specifications for the ONIL Solar Desk Lamp<em>:</em></strong>

<strong>Material:</strong> plastic.

<strong>Solar Panel<em>:</em></strong> it has a 20-year useful life, charges batteries in 8 hours and provides 6 to 8 hours of light.

<strong>Moveable Metallic Cable<em>:</em></strong> to set the light to where it is needed.

<strong>Hanging Hook<em>:</em></strong> allows the lamp to be set in a safe place.

<strong>Light Emitting Diodes (LED<em>):</em></strong> has 12 intense light emitting diodes.

<strong>Button<em>:</em></strong> to turn the lamp on and off.

The <strong>ONIL Desk Lamp</strong> is characterized by its ability to work either with solar light, which makes it more economical, or with <strong>3 AA NiCad or NiMH rechargeable standard batteries</strong>; there is no need for alkaline batteries.  This innovative system allows you to light for over five hours and recharge more than a hundred times.  It has 12 high-durability and high-lighting bulbs, which allows you to light bigger areas longer.

<strong>Instructions for the use of the ONIL Solar Desk Lamp<em>:</em></strong>

<strong>WITH SOLAR ENERGY<em>:</em></strong>

Set the panel on a sunny area.  Connect the lamp and a light will turn on, which indicates it is charging.  Leave it connected for 12 hours.

Turn it on by pressing the front button.  Perform the same action to turn it off.

The lamp has an adjustable angle.

<strong><em>WARNING:</em></strong>

Charge the battery immediately after the power runs out; do not charge longer than 24 hours.  If the lamp is not used for an extended period of time, it is recommended that the battery be charged every 3 months for a period of 4 hours to not affect its useful life.

&nbsp;
<h3><strong>ONIL Rechargeable Water Resistant Solar Flashlight</strong></h3>
<strong><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products-2/attachment/flashlightgraphicsmall/" rel="attachment wp-att-405"><img title="FlashlightgraphicSmall" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/FlashlightgraphicSmall-300x265.jpg" width="300" height="265" /></a>
</strong>

<strong>Technical Specifications<em>:</em></strong> 1-pound weight

<strong>Fluorescent Strips<em>:</em></strong> they allow the flashlight to be found in the dark.

<strong>Solar Panel<em>:</em></strong> it has a 20-year useful life, charges batteries in 8 hours and provides 6 to 8 hours of light.

<strong>Material<em>:</em></strong> exterior high-water and -impact-resistant plastic, ergonomically designed to fit a hand.

<strong>Holding Hook<em>:</em></strong> useful to hook up the flashlight anywhere.

<strong>Battery Compartment<em>:</em></strong> works with 3 AA NiCad or NiMH rechargeable standard batteries.

<strong>Light Emitting Diodes (LED):</strong> has 6 intense light emitting diodes.

<strong>Why is the ONIL Solar Flashlight better than a conventional flashlight<em>?</em></strong>

There is a number of reasons why the ONIL Solar Flashlight is better than the conventional one.  For example, our flashlight is powered by solar energy and only uses three AA rechargeable batteries with a useful life of 750 to 1,000 individual nights, in each of which the user can enjoy an average of six to eight hours of use.  A flashlight with non-rechargeable batteries gives a maximum of fifteen hours of light and always diminishes the intensity of its light before exhausting its batteries, which are then thrown and replaced.

The Solar Flashlight is always ready when it is needed.  A regular flashlight has a natural battery discharge index of approximately 3% per month.

<strong>How does the ONIL Solar Flashlight work?</strong>

It is very simple – the photovoltaic panel generates electricity that goes through an energy administration system to be stored in the rechargeable batteries until it is used.

<strong>How is the ONIL Solar Flashlight charged<em>?</em></strong>

In order to completely charge the batteries, the panel needs to be exposed to the highest amount of solar light possible.  If the Flashlight is not going to be used in a frequent manner, it needs to be set at the foot of a window to keep it charged and ready to be used.  In average, 8 to 10 hours of direct light into the solar panel (complete charge) are enough to provide 6 to 8 hours of light.

<strong>How long do the batteries last?</strong>

They are designed so that the chemical reaction has a minimum of 750 to 1,000 charge-and-discharge cycles before being replaced.

<strong>LED Technology (light emitting diodes<em>):</em></strong>

One light emitting diode produces light in an electroluminescent way.  Electroluminescence is an optical and electrical phenomenon in which a material produces light in answer to an electrical current that passes through the same material.  The light emitting diode is a small and compact object which wouldn’t light up large areas on its own; many of them together surely would, though.  The more diodes that are together, the more light will be obtained.  LED’s used in the Flashlight have a 100,000-hour useful life compared to the 100-hour life of an incandescent bulb that wastes most of the energy in heat.
<h3><strong>How to Help:</strong></h3>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Sponsor an ONIL Product</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Donate a stove, water filter or any other ONIL product (<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/onil-products/onil-product-selection/">see a full list of ONIL's full product selection</a>) and generationally change a family. Each stove and water filter combination costs only <strong>$250</strong> and can change the lives of generations of people. Each stove you donate will be installed in Guatemala by one of our staff or a volunteer mission team. They make excellent gifts, especially for birthdays or holidays! <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/donate/" target="_blank">Click here to make a donation</a>.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><strong>Participate in a Stove Installation Team </strong>
<ul>
	<li>Join an existing HELPS stove team to install these products side by side with Guatemalan families inside their homes. <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/" target="_blank">Click here to fill out a volunteer application</a>.</li>
	<li>Form your own stove team and bring your family, friends, or employees to work together on a project. Call us at 1-800-414-3577 or <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/contact/">fill out our contact form </a>to get started!</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Retained Heat Cooker (RHC)</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products/onil-product-selection/onil-retained-heat-cooker-rhc/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 15 Dec 2010 10:13:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products-2/attachment/rhcookergraphicsmall/" rel="attachment wp-att-408"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-408" title="RHCookerGraphicsmall" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/RHCookerGraphicsmall-300x265.jpg" width="299" height="263" /></a>

As HELPS examined the world of rural Guatemalans, it became clear that changing the way people lived within the home was critical for a sustainable reduction in poverty.  The initial <strong>Plancha Stove</strong> and then the<strong> Nixtamal Stove </strong>proved to transform the rural Guatemalan home.  However in looking at ways to further these types of solutions, HELPS developed the <strong>ONIL</strong> <strong>Retained Heat Cooker</strong>.

Food that has been brought to a boil on the <strong>Plancha Stove,  </strong>can be placed into the <strong>Retained Heat Cooker</strong> where due to a high level of insulation, the food can continue to cook using  its own heat.  This allows the family to have more freedom as this solution requires no monitoring or maintainance.  This device also saves firewood and therefore money, which allows women freedom in devising individual uses depending on their needs.
<h3></h3>
<h3><strong>How to Help:</strong></h3>
<ul>
	<li><strong>Sponsor an ONIL Product</strong>
<ul>
	<li>Donate a stove, water filter or any other ONIL product (<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/onil-products/onil-product-selection/">see a full list of ONIL's full product selection</a>) and generationally change a family. Each stove and water filter combination costs only <strong>$250</strong> and can change the lives of generations of people. Each stove you donate will be installed in Guatemala by one of our staff or a volunteer mission team. They make excellent gifts, especially for birthdays or holidays! <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/donate/" target="_blank">Click here to make a donation</a>.</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li><strong>Participate in a Stove Installation Team </strong>
<ul>
	<li>Join an existing HELPS stove team to install these products side by side with Guatemalan families inside their homes. <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/" target="_blank">Click here to fill out a volunteer application</a>.</li>
	<li>Form your own stove team and bring your family, friends, or employees to work together on a project. Call us at 1-800-414-3577 or <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/contact/">fill out our contact form </a>to get started!</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Economic Development - Program Information</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/economic-development/economic-development-program-information/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 05 Jan 2011 03:21:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Soft corn varieties for human consumption are grown in extensive areas of the highlands of Guatemala. Farmers own small farms and phase limitations in capital and technology and grain production is generally low. However, high enough sustainable yields can provide adequate income to sustain the household and provide savings to invest in farm improvement.</p>

<p>According to HELPS International, a NGO working in Guatemala in diverse areas of poverty alleviation, the farmer's family in rural Guatemala needs approximately 1,53 kg of corn per year, but  the traditional method of growing corn yields only about 1,000 kg of corn per year (FAO-PESA 2008).  The head of the family has to work outside his community to obtain the resources to purchase the additional corn for the year. Increasing the ability of farmers to grow higher yields is one way of helping farmers to obtain a better way of life.</p>

<p>Yield potential and nutrient needs differ among agro-ecological corn growing zones. This results in different growing conditions which require different nutrient recommendations and management. Knowing that soil testing is rarely used by small farmers, a site specific nutrient management approach, based on the omission plot technique, was developed to study the influence of local agro-ecological conditions on nutrient requirements as a tool to develop fertilizer recommendations to achieve high sustainable yields.</p>

<p>Main limitations of corn producers in the highlands are soil degradation (erosion), declining soil fertility and inadequate technical assistance. Work conducted in the past with small farmers in the highlands of South America has demonstrated that plant population and nutrient management can improve and sustain high enough yields satisfy food need and to help farm income.</p>

<p>Fertilizer recommendations used in the soft corn producing areas of the highlands do not satisfy the nutrient needs for high yields. One only nutrient recommendation is used for extensive areas of production, assuming that nutrient needs are constant in time and space. Improvement of corn production in the region needs a more dynamic approach in terms of nutrient management.</p>

<p>Yield potential and nutrient needs differ among agro-ecological zones. This results in different growing conditions which require different nutrient recommendations and management. Knowing that soil testing is rarely used by farmers, a site specific nutrient management approach, based on the omission plot technique, was developed to study the influence of local agro-ecological conditions on nutrient requirements as a tool to develop fertilizer recommendations to achieve high sustainable yields.</p>

<p><a rel="attachment wp-att-838" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/economic-development/attachment/programdifferentiationphoto-copy/"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-838" title="ProgramDifferentiationPhoto copy" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/ProgramDifferentiationPhoto-copy.jpg" alt="" width="413" height="227" /></a></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Economic Development - Tomás Caal</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/economic-development/economic-development-tomas-caal/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 05 Jan 2011 15:32:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: left;"><strong>Tomás Caal (Chimuis Tanchi) - "</strong>One afternoon, after finishing the reinforcement fertilization, Don Leonel an agricultural technician, approached the community’s committee President to inform him that MOSAIC and HELPS International would be sending extra fertilizer for our fields - it left us pretty surprised.  That same day, we were talking about the good development in our fields; we compared them to the ones we had last year when we hadn’t joined the Corn Program.  The technician explained to us that the purpose of this special fertilizer is to improve the nutrition level of the grain, which would have a positive impact in our families’ diet.  Our committee coordinated everything and we received the fertilizer; we applied it three days after the application of the reinforcement fertilizer.  We are very happy because we can see the good development of our corn crops, the good color in their leaves and we are confident that this year, with MOSAIC and HELPS International’s support, we’ll get better production."</p>

<p style="text-align: left;"><a rel="attachment wp-att-828" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/economic-development/attachment/manincornfield/"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-828" title="ManInCornField" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/ManInCornField.jpg" alt="" width="489" height="366" /></a></p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Economic Development - Santiago Choc</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/economic-development/economic-development-santiago-choc/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 05 Jan 2011 15:42:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Santiago Choc</strong> (Chiquisis) - After a work day in the field, we get together with the family and talk about our everyday experiences - good and bad.  We remember how in past years we had a hard time acquiring agricultural products for our crops and how during the harvest time we obtained very low productions leaving us not being able to sleep thinking how were we to fulfill our families food needs.  This year is different; we have followed the technicians’ advice and the plantations are developing very well.  This has made us trust even more the Program, MOSAIC and HELPS International’s personnel, who constantly train us.  A week ago, we talked with other members of the community and we’ve let them know that this Organizations have provided us with additional fertilizer that has been applied to the plantations, that will provide us a more nutritious grain and will allow our kids to have a better diet.</p>

<p><a rel="attachment wp-att-830" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/economic-development/attachment/santaigochoc-2/"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-830" title="SantaigoChoc" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/SantaigoChoc.jpg" alt="" width="400" height="366" /></a></p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>How to HELP</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/how-to-help/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 05 Jan 2011 20:43:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>If you are interested in joining one of our specialized construction teams, please visit our <span style="text-decoration: underline;">Get Involved</span> page to learn more. A HELPS Leader will then contact you for more information. Construction teams work to implement specific home improvements as an integral part of transforming the home. If you would like to speak with us directly, please call 800-41-HELPS (800-414-3577) or email info@helpsinternational.org.</div>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_google-plus-description</wp:meta_key>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>HELPS Medical Teams</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/healthcare/overview/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 05 Jan 2011 21:17:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3 style="text-align: left;"><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Mission-trips-Calendar-2014.pdf">Mission trips Calendar 2014</a></h3>
HELPS International has developed a system of volunteer medical teams to address the healthcare crisis in rural areas of Latin America. Our medical teams are comprised of 70- 100 members, from physicians and surgeons to nurses and support staff. HELPS teams are organized by a system of local chapters throughout the United States. If you would like to join a medical team, please <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/">fill out our online application</a>. Below is a list of some of our current volunteer chapters. To learn more about each team, click on the links below (if applicable):
<h5><strong><a href="https://www.facebook.com/ONIL.HELPS/posts/10151984897094852">Bakersfield Medical Team</a></strong></h5>
<h5><strong><a href="http://www.cascademedicalteam.org/">Cascade Medical/Construction Teams </a></strong></h5>
<h5>Centro Minnesota Medical Team</h5>
<h5><strong>Dallas Medical / Construction Team I</strong></h5>
<h5><strong><a href="https://www.facebook.com/ONIL.HELPS?filter=2#!/groups/494908710563436/">Dallas Esperanza Medical/Construction Teams</a></strong></h5>
<h5>Los Angeles Medical Team I</h5>
<h5><strong><a href="http://www.helpsla.com/">Los Angeles Medical Team II</a></strong></h5>
<h5><strong><a href="https://www.facebook.com/pages/Michigan-Helps-Medical-Team/183383048367166">Michigan Medical/Construction Teams</a></strong></h5>
<h5><strong><a href="http://www.sagemission.org/">SAGE - San Antonio Guatemalan Endeavor Medical/Construction Teams</a></strong></h5>
<h5><strong><a href="http://www.complexionsrx.com/sandiegohelps.html">San Diego Medical/Construction Teams</a></strong></h5>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Karin Larrave&#039;s Story - Northwestern Mutual</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/partner/karen-larrave-of-northwestern-mutuals-story/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 11 Jan 2011 22:32:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>
<p id="internal-source-marker_0.42400267464108765">My name is <strong>Karin Larrave</strong>, and I am a wealth management advisor with <a href="http://www.karinlarrave.com/"><strong>Northwestern Mutual</strong></a>. Five years ago, I had the opportunity to get involved with HELPS International, and since then, it has become a very important part of my life and my family's life.</p>
<img class="aligncenter size-medium wp-image-1074" title="126" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/1261-300x199.jpg" width="300" height="199" />

In 2007, I had the opportunity to travel to Guatemala with a HELPS team to help with the installation of the ONIL stoves in the town of Santa Avelina. During my trip, I was amazed at how something so small and simple, like an efficient stove, can drastically change the lives of people in need. After I experienced HELPS' motto, "Changing Lives" first hand, I was thoroughly compelled to become more involved with HELPS International. It has been my honor and privilege to serve as one of the main sponsors for HELPS' fundraising events over the past 5 years.

</div>
As a woman born in Guatemala, raised in Mexico City, and now a U.S. citizen, I truly believe that the strongest people in society have an obligation to help those weaker and less fortunate. I strive to live this out in my everyday life, especially in my business. Dr. Pedro Franco once said to me, "The reason I work with you as opposed to anybody else in the financial industry is because you show me that you care first." Comments like these remind me that I am in this world in order to help others to the best of my ability. The people and the mission of HELPS International enable me to pursue this goal.

I am thankful for the opportunity to contribute to the medical missions and various other programs of HELPS International by being a sponsor. I strongly encourage doctors, business owners, and high school students alike to get involved in any way possible. Being a sponsor, volunteering for a medical or a stove team, or attending the fundraising events are all great ways to get involved and make a difference. It is a joy to be a part of what HELPS is doing in Latin America. I have loved every second of it and I look forward to future years!]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Volunteer</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 11 Apr 2011 16:30:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: center;"><img class="size-medium wp-image-3615 alignright" alt="volunteer pics" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/volunteer-pics-300x168.jpg" width="299" height="156" /><em><strong>Whether you want to join a mission team or help organize a special event, there is a volunteer experience available for everyone.</strong></em></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><strong><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/" target="_blank">Mission Trip Volunteer Application</a></strong></em></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><strong><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Mission-trips-Calendar-2014.pdf">Mission trips Calendar 2014</a></strong></em></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><em><strong><a title="General Packing List for Mission Teams" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/3861-2/" target="_blank">Suggested Packing List for Mission Teams</a></strong></em></p>

<h2></h2>
<h2><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/healthcare/"><img class=" wp-image-1367 alignleft" title="1.18- 001 (13)" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/1.18-001-131-300x136.jpg" width="249" height="155" /></a><a title="Healthcare" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/healthcare/">Healthcare</a></h2>
Each medical team is comprised of roughly 80 medical and non-medical volunteers. HELPS provides both immediate medical relief and outreach programs in preventative health. Lend a helping hand and change the lives of those with little or no access to healthcare. <a title="How Medical Mission Teams Work" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/medical-mission-teams-work/">Click here to learn more about how a Medical Mission Team works</a>. Please fill out our <a title="Online Volunteer Application Form" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/">online application </a>and a team leader will contact you.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/overview/"><img class="alignleft  wp-image-1372" title="Scano, Jim (51)" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Scano-Jim-512-300x274.jpg" width="255" height="198" /></a>
<h2><a title="ONIL Overview" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/overview/">Community Development/ONIL Products</a></h2>
Through the installation of ONIL Products such as the Plancha stove and water purifier, construction teams provide a complete home transformation that has an immediate impact on the life a rural family. Join a team, comprised of volunteers of all ages and talents, and make a lasting impact on a family and their communitiy. <a title="How A Community Development Mission Team Works" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/community-development-mission-team-works/">Click here to learn more about how a Community Development Mission Team works</a>. Please fill out our <a title="Online Volunteer Application Form" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/">online application </a>and a team leader will contact you.

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/events/"><img class=" wp-image-1645 alignleft" title="208104_10150146360140356_534610355_6896179_1719246_n" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/208104_10150146360140356_534610355_6896179_1719246_n-300x200.jpg" width="259" height="189" /></a>
<h2><a title="Events" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/events/">Special Events</a></h2>
<span style="font-size: medium;"><span style="font-size: 15px;">Help coordinate special events that allow HELPS to continue their work in Central America and Mexico. From fundraisers such as The HELPS Mariposa Gala in Dallas and Guatemala City, to local chapter golf tournaments, to awareness events throughout the United States, there is an opportunity for everyone to help. For more information, contact Amanda Walker at 972-386-2901 or <a href="mailto:awalker@dillongage.com">awalker@dillongage.com</a>.</span></span>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

				<title>Videos</title>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Darkness To Light
[embed]http://vimeo.com/23257578[/embed]

<hr />

<h2>Video Gallery</h2>
<a class="lbpModal" href="http://player.vimeo.com/video/10804348"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-132" title="10 Days in Guatemala: The Juan Castro Story" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/04/juan-270x150.jpg" alt="" width="162" height="90" /></a> <a class="lbpModal" href="http://player.vimeo.com/video/17377844"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-704" title="Dr. Phil Boyle" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/DrPhilBoyleThumb-270x150.jpg" alt="" width="162" height="90" /></a> <a class="lbpModal" href="http://player.vimeo.com/video/11993896"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-724" title="Circle of Hope" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/05/CircleofHopeThumb-270x150.jpg" alt="" width="162" height="90" /></a> <a class="lbpModal" href="http://player.vimeo.com/video/21807747"><img class="alignnone size-thumbnail wp-image-1729" title="Guatemala Event" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/guatevent-270x150.jpg" alt="" width="162" height="90" /></a>

	<item>
				<title>ONIL Product Selection</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products/onil-product-selection/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 15 Apr 2011 15:33:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=1652</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="wp-image-4094 alignnone" alt="Winged Stove" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/Great-pic-of-stove-and-cement-flooring-286x300.jpg" width="168" height="199" /><img class="wp-image-3966 alignleft" alt="Water Filter" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/Water-Filter-232x300.jpg" width="154" height="198" /><img class="wp-image-2850 alignleft" alt="PRODUCTOS-ONIL-H" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/PRODUCTOS-ONIL-H-300x225.jpg" width="233" height="198" />
<p style="text-align: left;"></p>
<p style="text-align: left;"></p>
&nbsp;

&nbsp;

Basic home improvements and more efficient kitchens can transform a family's life. Living in a smoke-free environment, drinking purified water, and reducing the amount of firewood usage by 70% dramatically improves quality of life. The following is a list of the ONIL Products invented to address the concerns found within the communities we serve:
<div>
<ul>
	<li><a title="Griddle Stove" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products-2/onil-griddle-stove/">Plancha Stove</a></li>
	<li><a title="Nixtamal Stove" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/onil-products/onil-product-selection/onil-nixtamal-stove/">Nixtamal Stove</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/onil-products/onil-product-selection/onil-water-filte/">Water Filter</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/onil-products/onil-product-selection/onil-institutional-stove/">Institutional Stove</a> (for schools and other institutions)</li>
	<li><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/onil-products/onil-product-selection/onil-retained-heat-cooker-rhc/">Retained Heat Cooker</a></li>
	<li><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/onil-products/onil-product-selection/onil-solar-desk-lamp/">Solar Desk Lamp &amp; Rechargeable Water Resistant Flashlight</a></li>
</ul>
</div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>A Word From Our President</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/about-us/a-word-from-our-president/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 May 2011 14:41:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=1997</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Welcome to HELPS International. We are an organization that is making differences in people’s lives whether they are a partner, a volunteer, a patient, a farmer or anyone that is involved in our programs.   Not only do we believe that we can, but we have been actively implementing our programs and ideas in Guatemala since 1984 and now in Mexico, El Salvador, Honduras and Nicaragua.

The programs outlined in this website are not “on a napkin at dinner”, nor in a futuristic study, nor in a speech, but are real time, right now, as you read this letter.  Please browse through our website and find out more about our market based, sustainable, prosperity producing programs of integrated poverty reduction.  Learn how you can get involved directly or indirectly with HELPS through volunteering on a mission team, supporting us financially, becoming a corporate partner, or supporting us with your prayers and ideas.

We are an organization that believes that the programs outlined in this website can help transform an individual, community and country but we need your help to do this.   Become a part of an organization made up of people that have left their “couch” and will never return. Those who have taken action have been forever changed and are leaving a legacy of changed generations.  Get involved, accept life’s great challenges, and create for yourself experiences that are breathtaking in their truth, beauty, simplicity and stark reality.  Join us; don’t wait, because history doesn't.  Welcome to HELPS International!

Sincerely,

Stephen W. Miller, President of HELPS International]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:meta_key>_yoast_wpseo_opengraph-description</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Education</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/education/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 31 May 2011 17:32:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=2075</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[caption id="attachment_3546" align="alignright" width="310"]<img class="wp-image-3546 " alt="Educ photo 2" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/Educ-photo-2-300x174.jpg" width="310" height="180" /> Teacher reading to students in a classroom at HELPS' William M. Botnan School in Santa Avelina, Guatemala.[/caption]

In all societies, basic education is a priority if we are to be able to have a future for the family or a country.  Across Central America and Mexico, education in rural areas, especially those with indigenous languages, have been woefully inadequate.  It is said that out of the 13,000,000 people in Guatemala, over 2,000,000 children, mostly from rural indigenous areas, never see a school.

&nbsp;

<span style="color: #000000;"><strong>Historically</strong></span>

In the 1970's, HELPS co-founder Paul Townsend began literacy classes in the remote IXIL area of Quiche, Guatemala.  In the 1980's, David  Metzler, HELPS director at the time, began working in this Mayan area and supported the educational effort in the remotest of villages, Santa Avelina.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_3545" align="alignleft" width="270"]<img class=" wp-image-3545  " alt="educ photo 3" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/educ-photo-3-300x235.jpg" width="270" height="212" /> Young student studying with classmates[/caption]

In 1996, at the request of the elders in this village, HELPS built and now manages a private, experimental, primary school in rural Quiché.  In the 1990's Lois O'Neal took on the job of education director with a focus on training teachers and proving that children in these remote villages, who only spoke an indigenous language, could not only learn but compete with children educated in the main Guatemalan cities.

&nbsp;

Together with our sponsors, local teachers, 150 students, and the parents' committee, HELPS is defining the educational process required to prepare the students for the 21st century.  Not only are the children in Santa Avelina receiving a primary education, there are also HELPS students currently attending universities in Guatemala City.

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2810" align="alignright" width="270"]<img class="wp-image-2810  " alt="Education School Program Photo" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/EducationSchoolProgramPhoto.jpg" width="270" height="167" /> The William M. Botnan School, Photo by Tom Smoyer[/caption]

This success also serves as a positive blueprint to assist other communities in their healing from the thirty-six year civil conflict.  In the area of Santa Avelina, the after effect from this conflict is still a tangible reality.  On a first visit to Guatemala in the early 1980's, Stephen Miller, founder of HELPS, took a photo of  Guatemalans in the Nebaj refugee camps close to the area where the HELPS school is now located.  As he pointed to that photo hanging in his Dallas office, he said to HELPS visiting school director, Rosa Còrdova Pèrez,  “This is what I saw.  It motivated me to start HELPS and to keep working with all my heart.”  Rosa replied, “This is what motivates me too and this is why a copy of this picture also hangs in my office in the Santa Avelina school.”  This is the kind of positive "action" that has drawn the partners and people of HELPS together to make a positive difference in the country.

&nbsp;

<img class=" wp-image-3554 alignleft" alt="Educ photo" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/Educ-photo1-300x167.jpg" width="270" height="167" />Ethnic and linguistic minorities in countries the world over are struggling to have educational parity and access.  The solutions developed from this program will not only affect the burgeoning school-age Mayan children in rural Guatemala, but can be applied world-wide.  Volunteer U.S. educators are dedicated to defining the blueprint in partnership with the community.

In the beginning of HELPS' work in the Santa Avelina, a committee of women said, “We want a better life for our children.”  Thanks to your generous donations for the HELPS education program, our supporters bring hope for a better tomorrow.

&nbsp;

<span style="color: #000000;"><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/education/pep-partners-in-education-program/"><strong>Partners in Education Program (PEP)</strong></a> </span>

<span style="color: #000000;">Our “PEP” sponsorship program educates K-6th grade students at HELPS’ William M. Botnan School in Santa Avelina, Guatemala. <strong>For $42 per month, or $500 per year</strong>, you can sponsor a child by providing him or her with books, school supplies, highly trained teachers, and a safe and healthy learning environment. Also, Secondary Education Scholarships are available for 7th-12th grade boarding school students for $1,200 per year . To learn more about HELPS' sponsorship program and how to support a child, please <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/education/pep-partners-in-education-program/">click here.</a> For additional questions, please Contact Cheryl Weeks-Rosten at <a href="mailto:cwrosten@gmail.com"><span style="color: #000000;">cwrosten@gmail.com</span></a> or 989-631-5126. </span>

&nbsp;

[caption id="attachment_2726" align="alignright" width="243"]<img class="size-full wp-image-2726 " alt="ReadingTeam2011" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/ReadingTeam2011.jpg" width="243" height="182" /> HELPS Reading Team volunteers[/caption]

<span style="color: #000000;"><strong>How to HELP</strong></span>

<span style="color: #000000;">If you are interested in visiting the school, volunteering for our education program or<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/donate/"> donating to the PEP program</a>, please visit the <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/">Get Involved </a>page. For detailed information regarding our education program, please contact Cheryl Weeks-Rosten at <a href="mailto:cwrosten@gmail.com">cwrosten@gmail.com</a> or 989-631-5126.</span>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>PEP - Partners in Education Program</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/education/pep-partners-in-education-program/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 01 Jun 2011 18:16:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=2087</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<span style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">HELPS International believes the future of Guatemala lies in the education of the children. But we cannot do it alone. This is why HELPS developed the <strong>P</strong>artners in <strong>E</strong>ducation <strong>P</strong>rogram (<strong>PEP</strong>). <img class="alignright  wp-image-2089" title="pep1" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/pep1.jpg" width="200" height="151" /></span>

<span style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">The key to <strong>PEP</strong> is partnership. Through <strong>PEP</strong>, students, parents and partners work together to insure the success of HELPS' educational programs. HELPS believes in giving a hand-up rather than just a handout; for this reason, parents are required to contribute financially to the education of their child.  While the contribution may not be substantial by US standards, and not enough to cover the annual expenses of the school, it is significant to the families of HELPS students and reflects their commitment to their child's education.</span>

<span style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;"><img class=" wp-image-3540 alignleft" alt="Educ photo 2" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/Educ-photo-2-300x174.jpg" width="250" height="157" />The role of the partner in the <strong>PEP</strong> program is more than just financial, it is also one of friendship.  During the school year, students and partners develop a special bond that often lasts long after the students have completed their education at the HELPS school.  The relationship between the students and partners is so special that students refer to their partners as "madrina" (godmother) or "padrino"  (godfather). </span>

<span style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">Put a child on the right path with your contribution, and it can change the child's life. <span style="text-decoration: underline;">For only $42 per month, or $500 per year</span>, you can affect not only one person, but generations of people to come. You can help provide a quality education that will bring about change and give real hope for the future.<img class=" wp-image-3542 alignright" alt="guatemala kids" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/guatemala-kids-300x228.jpg" width="240" height="182" /></span>

<span style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">Become a PEP (Partner in Education Program) sponsor today and <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/donate/">make a contribution </a>that will last a lifetime. </span><span style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;">Call 1-800-41-HELPS (800-414-3577) or email us at info@helpsinternational.org or <a href="mailto:cwrosten@gmail.com">cwrosten@gmail.com</a>.</span>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Comadrona Project</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/healthcare/comadrona-project/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 01 Jun 2011 21:11:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=2104</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h3>Comadrona = Traditional Birth Attendant</h3>
<strong>PURPOSE</strong>

The Comadrona Project is a new project of HELPS aimed at reducing infant and maternal mortality in rural Guatemala.
<blockquote>"Yes! I had a baby who didn't breathe. I tried the stimulation you taught, but he still didn't breathe. Then I breathed into his mouth like you taught, and he started breathing."</blockquote>
<strong>BACKGROUND</strong>

The Comadrona Project specifically chose Santa Avelina, Quiche as the starting point for training traditional birth attendants. Santa Avelina, high in the mountains and with no local hospital, already had a strong connection to Helps International by way of a very successful elementary school (the William M. Botnan Experimental School) and through the implementation of various agriculture, stove and health innovations in that community. <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/ComadronaTraining.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2106" title="ComadronaTraining" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/ComadronaTraining-300x209.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="209" /></a>

The project was started after Lois Weeks researched local morbidity/mortality rates and cultural birthing norms in Santa Avelina. The World Health Organization notes that within better hygiene alone, many deaths can be prevented."Yes! I had a baby who didn't breathe.  I tried the stimulation you taught, but he still didn't breathe. Then I breathed into his mouth like you taught, and he started breathing."

In 2009 two Certified Nurse-Midwives and Lois, a retired pediatric nurse traveled to Santa Avelina to assess the knowledge-base of the local comadronas, their willingness and capacity for learning, as well as to provide teaching in maternal and infant care.  Upon their return visit in 2010, they found that the group of six comadronas remembered techniques learned the previous year and were excited for more in-depth training. The most elderly comadrona, for example, revealed that her efforts at neonatal resuscitation learned the previous year helped. She stated, "Yes!  I had a baby who didn't breathe.  I tried the stimulation you taught, but he still didn't breathe.  Then I breathed into his mouth like you taught, and he started breathing."  Other comadronas offered similar stories of success.

<strong>EDUCATION</strong>

A team of medical trainers works with the Comadronas using a family and community-focused, competency-based program "Home Based Lifesaving Skills" (HBLSS).  The materials were developed and tested by the American College of Nurse Midwives and specifically designed for use in low resource settings. It aims to reduce maternal and newborn mortality by increasing access to basic lifesaving measures with the home and by decreasing delays in reaching medical facilities.<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/CommunityHealthPromoter.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2138" title="CommunityHealthPromoter" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/CommunityHealthPromoter-300x228.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="228" /></a>

The curriculum utilizes large, laminated Take Action Cards demonstrating critical life-saving techniques through pictures that have been useful for teaching the pre-literate, Ixil speaking comadronas of Santa Avelina.  The curriculum provides specific instruction on how to perform techniques, helps to inform decision making during emergencies, and requires that the comadronas model back procedures.  The short term focus will be the most common causes of maternal death (postpartum hemorrhage and maternal infection), implementing hygienic birth practices, practicing neonatal resuscitation and transporting mothers or infants in cases of emergency.

<strong>VIDEO</strong>

Using indigenously dressed comadronas and in their Ixil language, short videos were produced on how to prepare for a hygienic birth in the home and an introductory film on what to do when a baby is not breathing.  These videos are valuable teaching tools for the comadronas, but will also be an innovative approach in the community.  The videos will be played at the local health clinic for patients and families, and will be promoted at other gatherings.  The more the community can help the comadronas with hygienic preparation, the greater the chance of success.  People are more likely to make impactful changes when they see their peers and family members in the videos.  These productions so far are in Ixil and Spanish.  The Ixil videos can be used in this region.  Since there are 23 indigenous languages in Guatemala, the Spanish version will be useful elsewhere with a local translator.  Our future film endeavors will include other health topics plus a video about community organization for handling emergencies, something that is imperative to prevent deaths of mothers and babies with life threatening problems.<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/ComadronaVideoProduction.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-2137" title="ComadronaVideoProduction" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/ComadronaVideoProduction-300x222.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="222" /></a>

&nbsp;

<strong>BIRTH KITS</strong>

Recently, The Lancet reported that family care alone (birthing in a clean setting, hygienic cord care, thermal care of newborns, breastfeeding promotion) can reduce neonatal mortality by 10-50% depending on the specific cause of mortality. For that reason, another crucial component of our project is to provide the comadronas with clean "birth kits."  The kits are composed of backpacks that contain the essentials to hygienic care and a clean birth setting: scissors and floss for cord cutting, bulb suctions, tarps for a clean birth space, soap, fingernail scrubbers, trays for cleaning instruments, Clorox, towels, as well as umbrellas, flashlights, and a rain poncho to help with night time walks to homes and baby hats to prevent heat loss in newborns. Full kits were supplied to each comadrona with plans to continue distributing and re-filling kits each subsequent year.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2104</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-06-01 13:11:22</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-06-01 21:11:22</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>comadrona-project</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>48</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[2]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>removesidebar_value</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[TRUE]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>removesubmenu_value</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[FALSE]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_page_template</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>addsidebar_value</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[Comadrona Project]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>Where We Work</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/about-us/where-we-work/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Jun 2011 17:25:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=2348</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="text-align: center;">HELPS International started its programs in Guatemala in 1984, and today HELPS has operations in</p>
<p style="text-align: center;">Guatemala, Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador, and Mexico.</p>
<img class=" wp-image-3750 alignleft" alt="Map of Guate honduras el salv" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/Map-of-Guate-honduras-el-salv-300x136.jpg" width="204" height="109" /><img class="wp-image-2354 alignleft" alt="GUA Map" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/GUA-Map-257x300.gif" width="184" height="205" /><img class="wp-image-3747 alignleft" alt="Map of Mexico" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/Map-of-Mexico-300x175.jpg" width="182" height="114" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Awards/Recognition</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/about-us/awardsrecognition/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 16 Jun 2011 20:49:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=2360</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h4><span style="color: #bdb76b;"><strong>The U.S. Chamber's BCLC (Business Civic Leadership Center) 2010 International Community Service Aware Nominee</strong></span></h4>
<h6>Dillon-Gage, as a result of it's work with HELPS International, was nominated for the 2010 International Community Service Award. Dillon-Gage CFO, Jon Christiansen, and Dillon-Gage was highlighted in a recent U.S. Chamber of Commerce publication. The article below shares about their involvement in the work of HELPS International and can be read below or the PDF can be seen <a title="Chamber of Commerce Article" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/United-States-Chamber-of-Commerce.pdf">here</a>.</h6>
<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/United-States-Chamber-of-Commerce.jpg"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-2207" title="United States Chamber of Commerce" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/United-States-Chamber-of-Commerce.jpg" width="616" height="475" /></a>
<h4><span style="color: #bdb76b;"><strong>2007 Health Award Laureate</strong></span></h4>
<h6>In November, 2007, The Tech Museum Awards in San Jose, California honored Donald O'Neal, HELPS International, as a Health Award Laureate for designing technology to build a safe, vented cooking stove:  the ONIL stove.  The ONIL stove is made of inexpensive concrete with an insulated ceramic lining and steel chimney.  The ONIL stove saves 70% of the wood normally used for cooking on open fire pits, and is designed to suit traditional Guatemalan cooking methods.  The ONIL stove virtually eliminates toxic smoke, protects the whole family from respiratory illness, burns, eye infections, and saves the equivalent of two days' time a week from gathering wood for cooking.</h6>
<h4><strong><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/awardsrecognition/attachment/dr-robles-award/" rel="attachment wp-att-2365"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2365" title="Dr. Robles Award" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/Dr.-Robles-Award.jpg" width="175" height="131" /></a><span style="color: #bdb76b;">Dr. Rodolfo Robles Award </span></strong></h4>
<h6>In 1998, President Alvaro Arzu of Guatemala presented HELPS International with the Order of Dr. Rodolfo Robles Award.  Mr. Stephen Miller, President of HELPS, accepted the award in the National Palace in the presence of two HELPS medical teams.</h6>
<h6>Established in December of 1955, the Order of Dr. Rodolfo Robles  is the highest award given by the Government of Guatemala to healthcare professionals and physicians for outstanding work in the area of public health.</h6>
<h4><span style="color: #bdb76b;"><strong>Ashden Awards </strong></span></h4>
<h6>On June 4, 2004, the Ashden Awards gave a monetary award to the HELPS International  ONIL Stove Project.  Using inspirational technology, Don O'Neal designed and developed a durable cooking stove which met rural families' cooking needs.  The ONIL stove eliminates indoor smoke and minimizes the risk of burns, while reducing wood use by 70% annually, providing health, economic, and social benefits for local communities, and also protecting the environment by reducing deforestation.</h6>
<h6>The judges commented:  "By bringing this sophisticated fuel-efficient stove into the homes of Guatemala's rural poor, HELPS is leading the way in the fight against crippling respiratory disease and horrifying burns, while also helping conserve the countries dwindling forests."</h6>
<h6>First Lady of Guatemala, Wendy de Berger, expressed her appreciation on behalf of the Government of the Republic of Guatemala for the work of HELPS International and commented:  "...sustainable energy is pivotal to the reduction of poverty, and poverty reduction is central to world peace..."   The ONIL stove also enjoys the support of the Shell Foundation, the Government of Guatemala and its "partner" non-governmental organizations throughout Guatemala and worldwide.</h6>
<h4><strong><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/awardsrecognition/attachment/monja-blanca-award/" rel="attachment wp-att-2366"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2366" title="Monja Blanca Award" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/06/Monja-Blanca-Award.jpg" width="175" height="131" /></a><span style="color: #bdb76b;">Monja Blanca Award </span></strong></h4>
<h6>On August 5, 2004, the Monja Blanca Award, Guatemala's civilian equivalent of the US Congressional Medal of Honor, was given to HELPS International. The Monja Blanca is the highest award given to foreign citizens for service to Guatemala.  Mr. Stephen W. Miller, HELPS' President, is speaking during the awards ceremony.</h6>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Mission and History</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/about-us/our-history/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 27 Jun 2011 16:31:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=2502</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h4 style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #3366ff;"><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Our Mission</span></span></strong></span></h4>
<p style="text-align: justify;">HELPS International is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization whose mission is to provide enduring programs of practical, social and spiritual value to the people in the developing world through a system of partnership and mutual responsibility.</p>

<h4 style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #3366ff;"><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Our History</span></span></strong></span></h4>
The HELPS’ journey  started in 1981 during Guatemala’s internal conflict.  The Guatemalan government contacted private US groups to see if those group could bring aid to Guatemala, which in turn was put into contact with  investment banker Stephen Miller and 50 or so others who subsequently went to Guatemala on a fact finding trip.

While in Quiche, Miller met an SIL translator, Paul Townsend who was giving the government briefings in the area.  Townsend and Miller developed a personal relationship and began working following the traditions of Christian service to help the people in the IXIL Triangle in Quiche.

Their initial work centered in aid programs, such as distributing food and blankets. It soon developed into building crude homes for widows and the first Dental programs.
<p style="text-align: justify;">HELPS was incorporated in 1984 and its programs have since developed into an integrated developmental philosophy.   Currently the program is an integrated program involving four main areas of education, healthcare, economic development and home transformation utilizing award-winning ONIL products.</p>

<h4 style="text-align: justify;"><span style="color: #3366ff;"><strong><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Our Philosophy</span></span></strong></span></h4>
<p style="text-align: justify;">The high levels of poverty in the developing world is at a critical stage and the window of opportunity to bring about real change is for this time in history.  HELPS is committed to assisting the rural population of the developing world through programs in education and literacy, medicine, and projects of practical, social concern and spiritual value. HELPS believes that the high levels of poverty throughout the world and our hemisphere is unsustainable and threatens the individual and the stability of our political and national institutions. Furthermore, HELPS believes that the window of time necessary to bring about transformation is short.  In order to address these issues, HELPS supports governmental and institutional progress and works for change on both the family and community levels.</p>
<p style="text-align: justify;">In respect to communities, HELPS strives for permanent change through its programs which promote mutual respect, responsibility and partnership within the local infrastructure based on the inherent value of the individual. This integrated approach helps ensure cohesiveness in cultural, spiritual and economic affairs within the community. Ultimately, HELPS believes that individuals, institutions, government and the private sector working together, can and must, help create prosperity and stability based on the market principles of individual responsibility and a free opportunity.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>The HELPS Reading Team</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2724</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2724</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>The HELPS ReadingTeam </strong>left Santa Avelina today after four days of coaching the teachers and helping in classrooms.  This team is a star-studded cast who have more collective years working with the HELPS school than any team yet fielded and several take leadership roles within the education division.  Each consultant deserves a page but here is a brief overview of the week from comments that <em><strong>Cheryl Rosten</strong></em>, team leader, emailed as they camped out in the school since last Saturday afternoon.

[caption id="attachment_2726" align="alignleft" width="243" caption="Cheryl Weeks Rosten is kneeling on the left in the front row. "]<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/ReadingTeam2011.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-2726   " style="margin: 4px;" title="ReadingTeam2011" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/ReadingTeam2011.jpg" alt="" width="243" height="182" /></a>[/caption]

<em> Many of her emails this week ended, “Must run, kids are singing.”  And that was the spirit that came through.  In spite of no water, cold rainy days, she had no complainers and everyone pitched in wherever they could help.  And that spirit reflects Cheryl’s contribution to HELPS.  She fundraises, communicates, coaches writing, leads teams, and is a wonderful friend to the Santa Avelina community. </em>

<em>Sign up for her graduation trip to Santa Avelina at the end of October.  It is an experience you don’t want to miss. cwrosten@gmail.com</em>

&nbsp;

The team kicked off their in-service on Monday with a July 4<sup>th</sup> lunch for the teachers.

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/RdngTmJuly42011.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2731" style="margin: 4px;" title="RdngTmJuly42011" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/RdngTmJuly42011.jpg" alt="" width="203" height="151" /></a>

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/RdngTmBJuly42011.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2732" style="margin: 4px;" title="RdngTmBJuly42011" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/RdngTmBJuly42011.jpg" alt="" width="203" height="152" /></a>

&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/KathyDavin2011.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2736" style="margin: 4px;" title="KathyDavin2011" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/KathyDavin2011.jpg" alt="" width="186" height="140" /></a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<em><strong>Kathy Davin</strong>, a bilingual reading specialist from the well-known Keys School in Arlington, VA 22201 and a volunteer with fourteen trips to SA, set the reading goals for the coaching consultants.  Kathy outlines the Santa Avelina reading intervention plan at http:// </em><a href="http://sahelpsschoolreading.wikispaces.com"><em>sahelpsschoolreading.wikispaces.com</em></a><em>.    It takes this kind of commitment and experience to understand how to help the Santa Avelina teachers with their unique bilingual education challenge.</em>

<em><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/LoydellSeward2011.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-2740" style="margin: 4px;" title="LoydellSeward2011" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/LoydellSeward2011.jpg" alt="" width="216" height="162" /></a><em><strong> Loydell Seward </strong>was on the first SA education team as the primary instructor.  Since that time, Nov 2001, she founded and managed two outreach areas in the HELPS Education Division—a field trip for the 5<sup>th</sup> graders and a scholarship for a female educator.  She returned for her last working trip with HELPS to coach the home visits of the preschool teachers based on her experience with home visits in the Parents as Teacher Program in Farmersville, TX.   Also on this trip was Heather Maynard, her granddaughter, who just graduated from high school.  Loydell has brought all five of her grandchildren to Guatemala and four of them to Santa Avelina.  Erin Treinen, HELPS host for the team, translated for Loydell.  It was Erin’s first time in SA and she said she loved it.</em></em>

[caption id="attachment_2744" align="alignright" width="117" caption="Millie Nylan"]<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/MillieNylan2011.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-2744 " style="margin: 4px;" title="MillieNylan2011" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/MillieNylan2011.jpg" alt="" width="117" height="153" /></a>[/caption]

<em><strong>Millie Nylan</strong>, a forever supporter of PEP and an educator, visited SA for the first time to work in the library</em><em> </em><em>with Felipa Lux Baten, our librarian.</em>

[caption id="attachment_2755" align="alignleft" width="199" caption="Dr. Donna Phillips working with the lower grade teachers and her translator, Carmen."]<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/DrDonnaPhillips2011.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-2755" style="margin: 4px;" title="DrDonnaPhillips2011" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/DrDonnaPhillips2011.jpg" alt="" width="199" height="149" /></a>[/caption]

[caption id="attachment_2757" align="alignleft" width="199" caption=" Donna posing with her PEP kids."]<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/DrDonnaPhillipsB2011.jpg"><img class="size-full wp-image-2757" title="DrDonnaPhillipsB2011" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/DrDonnaPhillipsB2011.jpg" alt="" width="199" height="149" /></a>[/caption]

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<em> </em>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

<em><em>Donna brought a hundred copies each of five beautiful Ixil books for young readers.   Many were authored and illustrated by our SA teachers.  In the group photo of the team, each member is holding one of these new books.  Through grants, neighborhood parties, help from Pacific University students, and lots of careful checking with our School Director, Rosa Córdova Pérez, Donna is producing, for the first time ever, engaging, illustrated, colorful, quality books for young Ixil readers.  One of the new books is entitled <span style="text-decoration: underline;">An</span>, which is Ixil for Ana.  The book, handsomely illustrated by Kathy Haney, is about a young girl in a rural village going to school.  Yesterday, Donna emailed, <strong>“</strong></em><strong>We have been using <span style="text-decoration: underline;">An</span> in the prepremaria and premaria - the children do love the book. I know this because this morning, prepremaria children arrived at school and unsolicited, without any teacher present, went to their cubbies, got the book and were reading it at their desks.”</strong>
</em>

<em><em>
</em></em>

<em>
</em>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
