	<item>
				<title>Awards</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products/awards/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Feb 2012 16:06:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=2860</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[HELPS International and its volutneers have been honored by numerous organizations throughout the world.  In particular, Don O'Neal the engineer behind the ONIL product line, has been recognized for his work.  Both Mr O'Neal and HELPS Vice President Richard Grinnell have been deeply involved in working with international agencies, organizations, initiatives and attending and presenting in conferences  involved in "home innovations" such as the world famous ONIL plancha stove.

June 24, 2004, Don O"Neal was a finalist in the <strong>Ashden Awards</strong>, the "Green Oscars",  in London, England and was awarded $17,000 in prize money for his famous stove design.

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Prince-Charles-w-Don-Oneal1.jpeg"><img class="size-full wp-image-2862 alignleft" title="Prince-Charles-w-Don-Oneal1" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Prince-Charles-w-Don-Oneal1.jpeg" width="350" height="240" /></a>

In this photo, Don O'Neal is being personally congratulated by Prince Charles, His Royal Highness, the Prince of Wales which was followed by congratulations from the First Lady of Guatemala, Mrs. Wendy de Berger, acknowledging Helps International’s work in Guatemala.

The Press Release was as follows: <em> </em>

<em>London – 24 June  2004 –The international winners of the prestigious Ashden Awards for Sustainable Energy 2004 were tonight announced at the Ashden annual awards ceremony in London.</em>

<em>The Ashden Awards rewarded seven projects from India, Pakistan, Kenya and Guatemala for their inspirational technologies that rely on renewable energy to provide social and economic benefits for local communities as well as protecting the environment.</em>

<em>The HELPS International ONIL stove, developed by Don O’Neal, was selected as a finalist among over 100 top sustainable energy projects in the world and received $17,000 for designing a pioneering smoke-free, fuel-efficient stove that cuts the wood required by 70% , eliminates indoor pollution and reduces the risk of burns associated with cooking on open fires. The judges commented: “By bringing this sophisticated fuel-efficient stove into the homes of Guatemala’s rural poor, HELPS is leading the way in the fight against crippling respiratory disease and horrifying burns, while also helping conserve the country’s dwindling forests<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Sir-Attenbrough2.jpeg"><img class="size-full wp-image-2863 alignright" title="Sir-Attenbrough2" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Sir-Attenbrough2.jpeg" width="300" height="199" /></a></em>

<em>The ONIL stove is a revolutionary stove design and implementation system that services the poorest by protecting women and children from burn and lung disease, the number one killer for children under 5 years old, and by giving women 2 days a week in time because of the wood savings.  This valuable time is then available for economic and social activity.</em>

<em>First Lady of Guatemala, Wendy de Berger, expressed her appreciation on behalf of the Government of the Republic of Guatemala for acknowledging the work of Helps International:  “…sustainable energy is pivotal to the reduction of poverty, and poverty reduction is central to world peace…”  The ONIL Stove also enjoys the support of the Shell Foundation, the government of Guatemala and its “partner” NGO’s throughout Guatemala and the United States.</em>

<em>The Awards, hosted by John Humphrys, saw finalists gather at the Royal Geographical Society, London with guest speakers Sir David Attenborough, and Jonathon Porritt, chair of the UK government’s Sustainable Development Commission.</em>

<em>Sir David Attenborough, who presented the prizes, commented: “I have found this evening both humbling and inspirational. We have much to learn from these remarkable award winners. I would like to thank the Ashden Awards for bringing our attention to this groundbreaking work”.</em><em>
</em>

<em>The Ashden Awards for Sustainable Energy – known globally as the ‘Green Oscars’ – now in their fourth year, reward inspirational and innovative renewable energy projects which both provide social and economic benefits to local communities and contribute towards protecting the environment by<span style="color: #008000;"><span style="color: #000000;"> curbing deforestation and</span> </span>reducing our dependence on fossil fuels thereby helping tackle climate change.</em>

<em>The finalists were also personally congratulated by HRH The Prince of Wales at a separate ceremony .  A spokesperson from the Palace said of the meeting: “The Prince of Wales was enormously encouraged to meet these remarkable people who are all making a substantial impact in alleviating poverty and helping protect our fragile environment both at the local and global level. They set a marvelous example which the Prince of Wales hopes will encourage others to follow”</em>

[caption id="attachment_2864" align="alignleft" width="300"]<img class="size-full wp-image-2864 " title="Laureate" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Laureate.jpeg" width="300" height="200" /> Laureate of Health 2007, Technical Museum of Innovation[/caption]

&nbsp;

In 2007, Don O'Neal was also a <strong>Laureate of Health</strong> for the prestigious Technical Museum of Innovation in San Jose, CA.  While competing against major companies and entities in the world for this honor, Don O'Neal's ONIL stove took its place in the highest levels of innovation and is clearly a solution for the times and the world.]]></content:encoded>

				<title>Awards</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products/2861-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Feb 2012 15:40:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=2861</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[HELPS  International, awarded $17,000 of prize money from the “Green Oscars” – Ashden Awards – for its famous stove design.

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Prince-Charles-w-Don-Oneal1.jpeg"><img class="size-full wp-image-2862 aligncenter" title="Prince-Charles-w-Don-Oneal1" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Prince-Charles-w-Don-Oneal1.jpeg" width="350" height="240" /></a>

-     Finalists personally congratulated by His Royal Highness Prince of Wales
-     First Lady of Guatemala, Mrs. Wendy de Berger, congratulates Ashden Awards for acknowledging Helps International’s  work in Guatemala.

London – 24 June  2004 –The international winners of the prestigious Ashden Awards for Sustainable Energy 2004 were tonight announced at the Ashden annual awards ceremony in London.

The Ashden Awards rewarded seven projects from India, Pakistan, Kenya and Guatemala for their inspirational technologies that rely on renewable energy to provide social and economic benefits for local communities as well as protecting the environment.

The HELPS International ONIL stove, developed by Don O’Neal, was selected as a finalist among over 100 top sustainable energy projects in the world and received $17,000 for designing a pioneering smoke-free, fuel-efficient stove that cuts the wood required by 70% , eliminates indoor pollution and reduces the risk of burns associated with cooking on open fires. The judges commented: “<em>By bringing this sophisticated fuel-efficient stove into the homes of Guatemala’s rural poor, HELPS is leading the way in the fight against crippling respiratory disease and horrifying burns, while also helping conserve the country’s dwindling forests</em>

The ONIL stove is a revolutionary stove design and implementation system that services the poorest by protecting women and children from burn and lung disease, the number one killer for children under 5 years old, and by giving women 2 days a week in time because of the wood savings.  This valuable time is then available for economic and social activity.

First Lady of Guatemala, Wendy de Berger, expressed her appreciation on behalf of the Government of the Republic of Guatemala for acknowledging the work of Helps International:  “…sustainable energy is pivotal to the reduction of poverty, and poverty reduction is central to world peace…”  The ONIL Stove also enjoys the support of the Shell Foundation, the government of Guatemala and its “partner” NGO’s throughout Guatemala and the United States.

The Awards, hosted by John Humphrys, saw finalists gather at the Royal Geographical Society, London with guest speakers Sir David Attenborough, and Jonathon Porritt, chair of the UK government’s Sustainable Development Commission.

Sir David Attenborough, who presented the prizes, commented: <em>“I have found this evening both humbling and inspirational. We have much to learn from these remarkable award winners. I would like to thank the Ashden Awards for bringing our attention to this groundbreaking work”.</em>

<em><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Sir-Attenbrough2.jpeg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2863" title="Sir-Attenbrough2" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Sir-Attenbrough2.jpeg" width="300" height="199" /></a>
</em>

The Ashden Awards for Sustainable Energy – known globally as the ‘Green Oscars’ – now in their fourth year, reward inspirational and innovative renewable energy projects which both provide social and economic benefits to local communities and contribute towards protecting the environment by <ins cite="mailto:Martin%20Wright" datetime="2004-06-23T16:43">curbing deforestation and </ins>reducing our dependence on fossil fuels<ins cite="mailto:Martin%20Wright" datetime="2004-06-23T16:43"> -</ins> <del cite="mailto:Martin%20Wright" datetime="2004-06-23T16:43">.</del><ins cite="mailto:Martin%20Wright" datetime="2004-06-23T16:43">thereby helping tackle climate change.</ins>

The finalists were also personally congratulated by HRH The Prince of Wales at a separate ceremony .  A spokesperson from the Palace said of the meeting: <em>“The Prince of Wales was enormously encouraged to meet these remarkable people who are all making a substantial impact in alleviating poverty and helping protect our fragile environment both at the local and global level. They set a marvellous example which the Prince of Wales hopes will encourage others to follow”</em>

<em><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Laureate.jpeg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2864" title="Laureate" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Laureate.jpeg" width="300" height="200" /></a>
</em>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>How It Works</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/programs/onil-products/onil-product-selection/onil-griddle-stove/how-it-works/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 13 Feb 2012 16:35:15 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=2905</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Theory of Operation</strong>
Several factors working together make the HELPS stove efficient, safe and convenient. The cast concrete stove body is molded in fiberglass molds, providing a fast low cost way of producing a long lasting, low cost stove body.  The body, however only provides structure for the stove.  Two main factors make the stove fast heating and fuel efficient.

<strong>Complete combustion</strong>
In order for all energy in the wood to be converted to hot gases, it must be completely burned including the oil vapor that normally would be emitted as smoke.  Containing the fire in a insulated combustion chamber allows the fire to burn hot enough to consume the oil vapor.  Smoke is wasted fuel.  It is also a health hazard both inside and outside the house.

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Cumbustionchamber1.jpeg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2907" title="Cumbustionchamber1" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Cumbustionchamber1.jpeg" width="170" height="128" /></a>

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/test_stoves-1.jpeg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2908" title="test_stoves-1" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/test_stoves-1.jpeg" width="288" height="216" /></a>

The photo at the top shows a stove housing with the clay combustion chamber but without the insulation.   The insulation is pumice, a volcanic rock that is a very good high temperature insulation and quite cheap.

Burning the wood inside the insulated chamber creates a gas temperature that exceeds 1400 degree F.  At these temperatures, the gas vapors (smoke) ignite, adding energy to the fire, and are eliminated from the exhaust.

<strong>Efficient transfer to the pot</strong>
Once the energy from the wood has been efficiently transformed to hot gases, it must be efficiently transferred to the pot.  Energy that heats the stove body and is exhausted to the chimney is energy not available for cooking.  Wood ashes or pumice provides insulation that prevents the heat from being wasted heating the stove body.  Hot gases that do not touch the plancha also waste their energy.  The insulation fills the stove cavity to within 1 inch (2.5 cm) of the metal plancha.  In this way, all the hot gases come in contact with the cooking surfaces thereby transferring their energy to the pot and leaving only enough heat in the exhaust gases to provide a draft up the chimney.

Wood management such as drying the wood and splitting it to proper size is taught by the HELPS stove technicians.

Due to complete combustion, efficient heat transfer and wood management, the wood consumption (and carrying) is reduced by 60-70%.

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/wood_carrying.jpeg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2910" title="wood_carrying" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/wood_carrying.jpeg" width="172" height="252" /></a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2905</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-02-13 08:35:15</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-02-13 16:35:15</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>how-it-works</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>384</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[3]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_page_template</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;">HELPS Online Volunteer Application Form</h2>
<h4><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/Mission-trips-Calendar-2014.pdf">Mission Trips Calendar 2014</a></h4>
<h4>If you have trouble submitting this form online, please fill out the <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/2014-Electronic-Volunteer-Application.pdf" target="_blank">Electronic Version</a>, save it to your computer and email to <a href="mailto:wpedrero@dillongage.com">wpedrero@dillongage.com</a></h4>
[gravityform id="3" name="HELPS Online Application" title="false" description="false"]]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>How Medical Mission Teams Work</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/medical-mission-teams-work/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Sep 2013 16:22:27 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=3850</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[HELPS Medical Teams are scheduled from January through October every year. The teams are organized by local team leaders in various parts of the U.S. Each team consists of 60-80 volunteers, comprised of surgeons, Ob-gyns, general practitioners, anesthesiologists, dentists, nurses, pharmacists, translators, cooks, engineers, and other types of support personnel needed to assist the team. A volunteer does not need to have medical training to join a medical mission.

After submitting your <a title="online volunteer application" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/online-volunteer-application-form/">online application</a>, your information will be forwarded to a team leader, who will contact you while organizing the team. Please indicate on your online application the team/s you would be interested in joining, either by team name or number, so that your application can be forwarded to the appropriate team leader for consideration. The team leader(s) will be glad to answer any questions for you.

HELPS has a full-time staff in Guatemala to facilitate the teams’ in-country experience, and our main offices are located in Addison, Texas.

HELPS medical missions generally last 12 days. The usual planned agenda for a team is to stay in a hotel in Guatemala City the first night, travel by bus to the hospital the next day, and stay in the hospital while work is being done throughout the week. Hospital sleeping arrangements are dormitory style, using cots and sleeping bags. There are bathroom and shower facilities in the hospital, and you will be fed on-site by the kitchen team. The trip will be completed with a three-night R&amp;R stay at a hotel in the city of Antigua, and will conclude with a team banquet on the last evening you are there. Some teams follow a slightly different schedule, depending on the location the team plans to serve.

The cost of the trip for 2014 will be $2000.00* when departing with the team from designated departure cities.  The cost of the trip is considered a tax donation. All expenses (including air travel and required travel insurance) are covered in the cost, except for a few meals you will have on your own during your rest and relaxation in Antigua. Many of our team members have others donate on their behalf to help defray the cost of the trip. These donations are also 100% tax deductible if the checks are made out to HELPS International.

For more information, please call us at the HELPS office: 800-414-3577 or 972-386-2901, ext. 1148 or email us at: <a href="mailto:info@helpsintl.org">info@helpsintl.org</a>.

*Fees vary slightly by teams. Please check with your team leader(s) for actual cost verification.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>How A Community Development Mission Team Works</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/community-development-mission-team-works/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Sep 2013 16:34:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=3857</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[HELPS Community Development (stove installation) teams are generally scheduled from January through late November every year. The teams are organized by local team leaders all over the U.S. Each team generally consists of 10 to 20 volunteers, comprised of a variety of support personnel needed to assist with the construction and installation of clean cookstoves. After submitting your online application, your information will be forwarded to a team leader, who will contact you while organizing the team. Please look at the online team calendar and indicate on the application the team/s you would be interested in applying to, either by team name or number, so that your application can be forwarded to the appropriate team leader for consideration. The team leader will be glad to answer any additional questions for you.

The HELPS missions usually last between 10 and 12 days. The typical planned agenda for a team is to stay in a hotel in Guatemala City the first night, travel by bus to the construction/installation site, and stay at a local hotel while you work. Meals are generally provided as part of the trip. The trip will be completed with a brief stay in a hotel in the city of Antigua. Some teams follow a slightly different schedule depending on the location the team plans to serve.

The cost of the trip for 2014 will be around $2000.00* when departing with the team from designated departure cities. Your team leader will advise you of the specific amount you will need to pay, based on their individualized work plan. The cost of the trip is considered a tax donation. All expenses (including air travel and travel insurance) are covered in the cost, except for a few meals you will have on your own during your rest and relaxation time in Antigua. Many of our team members have others donate on their behalf to help defray the cost of the trip. These donations are also 100% tax deductible if the checks are made out to HELPS International.

For more information please call us at the HELPS office in Dallas: 800-414-3577 or 972-386-2901, ext. 1148 or e-mail us at: <a href="mailto:info@helpsintl.org">info@helpsintl.org</a>.

*Fees vary by teams. Please check with your team leader(s) for actual cost verification.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>General Packing List for Mission Teams</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/3861-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Sep 2013 16:45:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=3861</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h4 align="center"><b><span style="color: #000000;">Suggestion Packing List for Mission Teams:</span></b></h4>
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">1 suitcase, weighing no more than 50lbs. when full (to check) </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">1 carry-on bag</span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Water bottle </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Hat or sun visor </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Jacket or sweatshirt </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Light raincoat sturdy</span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Closed-toe shoes (hiking shoes, boots, athletic shoes)</span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Day pack, backpack, tote bag and/or fanny pack </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Insect repellent (with DDT recommended)</span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Washcloth &amp; towel (Microfiber highly recommended) </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Soap &amp; shampoo </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Toothbrushes (extra in case you drop or contaminate one) </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Shower shoes (flip flops, etc.)</span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Light sleeping bag / sleeping pad / pillow / sheets or blanket, if you prefer </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Camera &amp; film </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Small flashlight </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Alarm clock </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Batteries for electronics</span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Traveler’s checks or cash </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Passport &amp; neck pouch for passport </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Copy of passport and State issued ID inside luggage </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Airline tickets </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Antibacterial hand wipes and/or antibacterial lotion </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Tissues and/or bathroom emergency kits (toilet paper, seat protector and hand wipes) </span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Personal toiletry items, contact lens kit, medications, etc.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Light leather gloves (for stove installations only)</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Inexpensive Dusk Masks (for stove installations only)</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Inexpensive Protective glasses (for stove installations only)</span></li>
</ul>
<b><span style="color: #000000;">GENERAL TIPS:</span></b>
<ul>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Travel light with just a few changes. Too many clothes are a problem to manage and carry. You will be able to wash things out by hand during the week.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Don’t bring things that will be a temptation for others to take; don’t bring any item that is irreplaceable. Leave expensive jewelry and watches at home. Bring small binoculars and a good camera with film or digital camera.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">A water bottle is essential to carry to the site. (You will also need to keep your water bottle handy for teeth brushing. Tap water is non-potable.) Water will be provided for refills.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Put in a day pack or something with which to carry your water, lunch, and personal things to the construction site.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Clothes and shoes: (while on the bus and at the worksite)</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Females: Light-weight VERY loose fitting pants (<b>NO LOW RIDERS OR SHORTS</b>) or skirts and dresses that come below the knee. (Don’t forget a slip.)</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Tops that have at least short sleeves and are not tight. No strapless or spaghetti string tops. Modesty is the best policy. Absolutely no shirts with graphics or wording that can be interpreted as offensive by the locals or by fellow volunteers. </span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Males: Long pants (never shorts) Shirts with sleeves. (No muscle shirts.)</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Clothes for the Antigua portion are resort type clothes, shorts permissible, bathing suits for pool. Please remember you are representing HELPS at all times and be sensible to the locals. Streets in Antigua are paved in cobblestone; please be careful when wearing high-heeled shoes. </span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Hat or sun visor to protect you from the sun while you work. You will be at a high elevation and the sun can be harsh. </span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Sturdy, closed shoes are always recommended. Streets are dirty and sanitation is poor. Keep sandals for indoors only.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Jacket, sweatshirt, or sweater for mornings and evenings can be cool.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Light raincoat or umbrella unless you enjoy working in the rain.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">In most cases there will be electricity for hair dryer and curling iron if you want them.</span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #000000;">Traveler’s checks or dollars. There will be time to shop in the village for Mayan crafts.</span></li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>3861-2</wp:post_name>

		<wp:post_parent>1358</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
				<title>Additional Ways to Give</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/additional-ways-give/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 19 Nov 2013 18:38:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=3989</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2 style="text-align: center;"><span style="color: #000080;">Make Your Shopping Count By Supporting HELPS!</span></h2>
<h5 style="text-align: center;">Many grocery stores and online shops participate in community reward programs that will give a percentage of your purchases to HELPS. Please browse this list of participating stores to learn how to get involved. Thank you for thinking of HELPS while you shop!</h5>
<div id="_mcePaste">
<h3 align="left"><b><span style="color: #ff6600;">Amazon</span> <a href="http://smile.amazon.com" target="_blank"><img class="alignright size-full wp-image-4006" alt="Amazon Smile pic" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Amazon-Smile-pic.jpg" width="214" height="96" /></a></b></h3>
<p align="left">Visit <a href="http://smile.amazon.com/" target="_blank">http://smile.amazon.com/</a> and select Helps International from the drop down menu, and start shopping! Amazon will automatically store HELPS as the beneficiary of choice and will donate 0.5% of any eligible purchase to HELPS.</p>

<h3><strong><span style="color: #ff6600;">Kroger - Community Rewards Program</span><a href="https://customer.kroger.com/communityrewards.aspx" target="_blank"><img class="alignright  wp-image-4008" alt="Kroger Community Rewards" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Kroger-Community-Rewards.jpg" width="154" height="122" /></a></strong></h3>
<p align="left">Speak with a grocery store cashier or sign up at <a href="http://www.krogercommunityrewards.com/" target="_blank">http://www.krogercommunityrewards.com/</a> and connect your reward card with the HELPS’ ID# 94968. You must swipe your registered Kroger Plus Card or use HELPS ID when shopping for each purchase to count! Kroger will keep a running total of your purchases and each quarter of the year they will send HELPS a check for 1% of the total amount.</p>

<h3 align="left"><strong><span style="color: #ff6600;">Tom Thumb / Randalls - Good Neighbor Program</span><a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/TTGN-pic.jpg" target="_blank"><img class="wp-image-4004 alignright" alt="TTGN pic" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/TTGN-pic.jpg" width="186" height="119" /></a></strong></h3>
Print out <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/TTGN-pic.jpg" target="_blank">this form</a> with HELPS ID #13132 and return it to any Courtesy Booth. They will activate HELPS' account onto your reward card. Once you're signed up, Tom Thumb will keep a running total of your purchases and each quarter of the year they will send HELPS a check for 1% of the total amount.
<h3><span style="color: #ff6600;"><strong>Albertsons - Community Partners Program</strong></span></h3>
<p align="justify">Print <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Albertsons-scanner.jpg" target="_blank">HELPS Temporary Partners Card</a> to bring with you the next time you shop at your neighborhood Albertsons. Ask the cashier to scan the card which is specific to HELPS International. Once you’re signed up, Albertsons will ke<a href="http://www.albertsons.com/our-company/community-partners/"><img class="alignright  wp-image-4010" alt="Albertsons keytag" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/Albertsons-keytag.jpg" width="178" height="71" /></a>ep a running total of your purchases and each quarter of the year they will send HELPS a check for 1% of the total amount. Permanent Community Partner key tags can be provided by HELPS. If you are an Albertsons regular, please <a href="mailto:awalker@dillongage.com?subject=Albertsons%20Community%20Partners%20key%20tag">contact Amanda Walker at HELPS</a> and one will be mailed to you immediately.</p>
<p align="justify"><strong>*If you know of other stores not listed above that offer community reward programs, <a title="Contact Us" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/about-us/contact/">please let us know</a>!</strong></p>

</div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Women Helping Women</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/volunteer/4108-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Jan 2014 16:34:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?page_id=4108</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="size-medium wp-image-4109 aligncenter" alt="WHW logo" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/WHW-logo-300x152.jpg" width="300" height="152" />

Women Helping Women is an international program of HELPS where a group of women join forces to commit to improving the lives of mothers and children across Guatemala.  A network of women’s grassroots efforts, the campaign raises funds to join with HELPS International and implement ONIL Stoves and Water filters in Latin America.

&nbsp;

Each supporter of this program will be changing the lives of families all across Guatemala.  If a donor is able to come down to participate in a Women Helping Women project, they will in the course of their involvement have the opportunity to meet these families that they are helping.   We will also have ongoing progress reports on this entire initiative.

&nbsp;

Women Helping Women exemplifies the strength of women to change the world.  Every single donation contributes to change a village.  Every stove, every water filter, every contribution, every woman is necessary to make this change possible.

&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: center;">For additional information and to stay up to date, please visit our Facebook Page: <a href="https://www.facebook.com/HELPSwomenhelpingwomen">https://www.facebook.com/HELPSwomenhelpingwomen</a></p>

<h4 style="text-align: center;"></h4>
<h4 style="text-align: center;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">Thank you to our sponsors</span></h4>
<h4 style="text-align: center;">Alexa Jewelry</h4>
<h4 style="text-align: center;">Tupperware International</h4>
<img class=" wp-image-4129 alignnone" alt="WHW jenny and kids" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/WHW-jenny-and-kids-241x300.jpg" width="193" height="240" /><img class=" wp-image-4130 alignnone" alt="WHW Guate woman" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/WHW-Guate-woman-243x300.jpg" width="194" height="243" /><img class="alignnone  wp-image-4133" alt="WHW pics" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/WHW-pics-198x300.jpg" width="158" height="240" />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Doug the &quot;MacGyver&quot;</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/healthcare/2010/11/29/doug-the-macgyver/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 29 Nov 2010 17:42:59 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=234</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Some of you may remember the t.v. show, “MacGyver”.  You may remember that MacGyver (and his stylish Mullet hair) was the ever-resourceful, secret agent who could disable the nuclear bomb system of an evil empire with a paper clip.

A MacGyver on a HELPS Medical or Stove Team is someone  who keeps the team running mechanically and can fix just about everything.  They are invaluable, particularly on in a country where resources are limited and there are time pressures.

[embed]http://vimeo.com/16005965[/embed]

In this short video, Doug shares his experiences as a MacGyver having visited 40 or more times to Guatemala and Central America.  He and other volunteers have proved invaluable in helping medical professionals serve the people of Central America in a life-changing way.  Many volunteers like Doug find that as they work to help change the lives of others, their own life is the one that becomes changed for the better.  If you would like to become a volunteer like Doug or know someone who would, please contact us at: 1-800-41-HELPS or look here for more information.

<a rel="attachment wp-att-189" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/get-involved/attachment/dougmotorcycleguysmall/"><img class="alignnone size-medium wp-image-189" title="DougMotorcycleGuySmall" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/DougMotorcycleGuySmall-300x199.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="199" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Thank You Dan!</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2010/11/29/thankyoudan/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 29 Nov 2010 18:31:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=258</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Daniel Sanchez, former Medical Team Coordinator, has left the HELPS family to further pursue his career as an oncologist. As a child Daniel spent his summers working on a coffee plantation, which gave him a chance to see life outside of the city and to discover the true beauty of his country.

In Guatemala, students aspiring for a career in medicine begin a seven year program directly out of high school. Part of this program is designated for field study where students volunteer their services in the highlands. This is where Daniel began his relationship with HELPS which helped him to discover his exceptional skills connecting with patients and his ability to help in ways other than medicine.

Daniel has moved to the United States, and over the next several years he will work on his oncology residency. As he looks back, he reflects on how HELPS has shaped his perspective on his future career. “My plan was to remain in the states, but that changed after a year and a half with HELPS. I want to come back. I have always loved my country, and in working with HELPS I realized that I could do my part to change somebody’s life.”
<blockquote>
<h2><strong><em> “I encourage Guatemalans. There is a lot of need and all of us can help. It can be a real changing experience.”</em></strong></h2>
</blockquote>
HELPS wants to extend a great “Thank you, and Good Luck” to Daniel as he moves on.  Thank you Dan!

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/DannyPic.bmp"><img class="alignleft size-full wp-image-1594" title="DannyPic" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/DannyPic.bmp" alt="" /></a>

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>A Major Milestone: Graduation</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2010/11/29/graduation/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 29 Nov 2010 18:43:40 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=264</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div>

On October 28, 2010,  sixteen sixth graders from the William M. Botnan School in Santa Avelina, Guatemala, completed their elementary education.  The upstairs assembly room was filled with proud parents and children dressed in their finest for the two hour ceremony. After each graduate had received a diploma, a jacket and Spanish Bible, and posed for photos taken in front of the Guatemalan flag, the students enjoyed a chicken dinner prepared  by their teachers. On this occasion, volunteers from HELPS always present the children with a small gift to honor either promotion or graduation.

Since local public education only goes through 9<sup>th</sup> grade, HELPS offers scholarships so promising young people can continue their education. Most students are at Utatlan, a technical boarding school in Santa Cruz for grades 7-12.  On October 29, we saw our first three students graduate: one from the early childhood program and two from the bi-lingual secretarial program.  Proud relatives were present from Santa Avelina, even though it’s  a four hour bus ride one way.  PEPKIDS director, Cheryl Weeks-Rosten, stated,  “I’ve seen a lot of high school graduations in my career, but  seeing our girls walk across that stage was an incredibly rewarding experience that brought me to tears.”

The volunteers who give of their time in the educational branch of HELPS International are proud to invest in the lives of the young people of Guatemala and take joy in seeing the results of their commitment.  You too can take part by contributing to either the Partners in Education Program (PEPKIDS) for children in grades K-6, or to the Scholarship Program for young people in grades 7-12.

Click <a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/donate/" target="_blank">here</a> to learn more about the programs or <a href="https://secure.helpsintl.org/donations/online_donation.php?program_ID=3" target="_blank">here</a> to donate now!

<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/?attachment_id=378"><img class="size-medium wp-image-378 alignleft" title="Rosa&amp;PrettyGrad" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/RosaPrettyGrad-300x150.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="150" /></a>

</div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Dr. Boyle&#039;s Story</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/healthcare/2010/11/29/dr-boyles-story/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 29 Nov 2010 18:47:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=273</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<br class="spacer_" />

[embed]http://vimeo.com/17377844[/embed]

<br class="spacer_" />

Over 20 years ago Dr. Phil Boyle, an anesthesiologist from St. Cloud, MN, went on his first HELPS medical trip. At that time, this particular trip to Nebaj was HELPS' second medical venture thus far. HELPS has brought Dr. Boyle and his services to different parts of Guatemala including multiple trips to Nebaj, Chajul and San Cristobal. In January of 2011, he will be taking his 20<sup>th</sup> trip when he travels to San Cristobal with a medical team from Dallas, TX.

HELPS has created for Dr. Boyle a passion for the culture and people of Guatemala, which has profoundly affected his life and the lives of those around him both from a personal and professional standpoint. "Many of the people with whom I work - doctors, nurses and others - have participated in this work and this has provided a shared experience that binds us in a way that is universally positive."

Over the last twenty years, Guatemala has also become a large part of the whole Boyle family. Dr. Boyle’s involvement has brought his wife Kris, and all eight of their children back to Guatemala on numerous occasions. After experiencing numerous HELPS medical trips, all of his children have returned to experience the beautiful culture of Guatemala in their own travels.

Phil and Kris Boyle have adopted two children from San Cristobal, AV, and their oldest daughter Mary is married to a man from San Lucas Toliman. “I have received so much more than I have given. My time spent in Guatemala has helped me to realize what it is that brings happiness in this life, and it is not a lot of "stuff"."  – Dr. Phil Boyle]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>HELPS Bus Ready for Teams</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2010/12/09/helps-bus-ready-for-teams-2/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 09 Dec 2010 19:03:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=331</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In November 2010, after some modifications and repairs, the new bus donated to HELPS -The Chicken Bus- was ready for its first ride. All of HELPS Guatemala’s staff,along with Richard Grinnell – HELPS Vice President – went on a field trip to San LucasSacatepéquez and enjoyed a nice cup of “atol de elote”(drink prepared with cornmeal gruel).  The “Chicken Bus” is now used for local volunteer groups in communities nearby Guatemala City.</p>

<p><a rel="attachment wp-att-335" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2010/12/09/helps-bus-ready-for-teams-2/attachment/busphoto/"><img class="alignnone size-large wp-image-335" title="busphoto" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2010/12/busphoto-640x480.jpg" alt="" width="640" height="480" /></a></p>

<p><br class="spacer_" /></p>]]></content:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>

	<item>
				<title>Darkness to Light; a Story of Blind Faith</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/healthcare/2011/05/09/super-interesting-new-story/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2011 16:48:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=1844</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As Francisco walks out of HELPS' Eye Clinic and into the sunshine, he sees through tears of joy, the beautiful world around him for the first time in years. Like many Guatemalans, less than fortunate circumstances and events have left Francisco with few opportunities at creating a better life for him and his family. Having invested everything he had by bringing his savings along with his wife and kids, Francisco made the trip in hopes of having his sight restored and to once again be able to provide for the people he loves.
<blockquote>"We cannot change the world, but one patient at a time, and one donor at a time, the economies of scale are huge." - Dr. Corona</blockquote>
Inspired by faith in HELPS, Francisco made the trip. When a person takes a giant step with no guarantees and puts everything on the line as Francisco did, who will be there to in turn <em>give </em>hope? HELPS International volunteers give the gift of hope for a brighter future to the lives that they touch. HELPS' Programs foster relationships with the people that makes our programs more than just a band-aid. As HELPS President Steve Miller likes tell first-time volunteers, "It's a leap of faith." This leap is mutual from the patients perspective, whether it be a story similar to Fransico's or a mother sending her child in for an operation, blind faith gives strength in difficult times.

&nbsp;

This year, HELPS' Medical Team out of Dallas had the opportunity to work in cooperation with an eye clinic. Dr. Ponce is an opthamologist from Guatemala City, and after studying in New York he has returned to Guatemala and is working to run a system of eye clinics that will give free eye care to the 30,000 impoverished Guatemalans who suffer from eye problems. Dr. Jorge Corona of Dallas, was the leader of the eye team that staffed Dr. Ponce's San Cristobal Clinic during HELPS' visit there in January.

&nbsp;

"We cannot change the world, but one patient at a time, and one donor at a time, the economies of scale are huge." Dr. Corona touches on how he sees the HELPS Medical Mission affecting the larger problems faced by the Guatemalan people. Along with his volunteer staff he saw (x number of patients) During there visit to San Cristobal this January. Switzerland based Alcon, is the medicine company that made this eye team possible through the donation of the eye care products used in the clinic. Beth Zemkoski of Alcon joined the Dallas Team in January for her first trip working as Dr. Corona's Assistant. "I can honestly say that this experience has changed my life."  On the last night of the banquet, beth shares with the team her reaction to the happenings of the previous week, specifically referencing the day Fransisco's patches were removed after his surgery. "Every single person here has a story, and for me that story was Wednesday."

&nbsp;

Stories like these stand as a testament to HELPS, and what can be accomplished when people take that leap, and give a little more of themselves than they thought they could. When these steps are taken from both sides, it truly shows the great strides that can be made towards alleviating poverty. When HELPS volunteers make a leap of faith, meeting the Guatemalan people half way, a chance at a brighter future is secured and lives are changed.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Dallas Team Leadership</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2011/05/09/dallas-team-update/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2011 19:21:39 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=1868</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[For many HELPS volunteers, the commitment to the cause far exceeds the boundaries of the annual ten days spent in Guatemala. In the smiling faces of the Guatemalan people, they are reminded of why they continue to push forward with efforts towards poverty reduction. The time spent in Guatemala serves as a reunion for the HELPS family and the Guatemalan people, inspiring us all to keep the cause close heart throughout the year. Steve and Alicia Harris from Dallas made their 11<sup>th</sup> trip to Guatemala this January to support the efforts of HELPS’ Healthcare Program. As an OB/GYN, Steve gains through medical missions a new perspective on his profession and on his life that inspires him to keep coming back.
<blockquote>You hit the ground running, and you’re changing lives. It’s not just a band-aid, its something that lasts.  This is the real deal. This is real medicine. What you give goes directly to the care of people.</blockquote>
“I thought it would be one trip,” Steve says as he recalls his thoughts regarding the first trip. Trends in “medical tourism” caused skepticism, as this practice is largely frowned upon in the medical community. Steve talked with us about what sets HELPS apart from other Healthcare efforts:

<em>“ I didn’t want to go and just hand out pills, I wanted to do what God has given me some skill with, which is connecting one on one with patients. HELPS has been here a long time. The infrastructure is here and the impact is amazing. You hit the ground running, and you’re changing lives. It’s not just a band-aid, its something that lasts. This is the real deal. This is real medicine. What you give goes directly to the care of people.”</em>

<a rel="attachment wp-att-1870" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2011/05/09/dallas-team-update/attachment/aliciasteveweb-1-2/"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1870" title="AliciaSteveWeb-1" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/AliciaSteveWeb-11-300x199.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="199" /></a>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>dallas-team-update</wp:post_name>

	<item>
				<title>Mauricio Rosales</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2011/05/09/mauricio-rosales/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2011 19:29:29 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=1881</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a rel="attachment wp-att-1883" href="http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2011/05/09/mauricio-rosales/attachment/mauriciophoto-copy2/"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1883" title="MauricioPhoto copy[2]" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/MauricioPhoto-copy2-300x190.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="190" /></a>

“This is the fist time they’ve seen so many blonde people,” laughed Mauricio as he led the group up the hill. Mauricio Rosales is a HELPS employee working for the Home Transformation program, specializing in stove team leadership. He has taken a construction team into the village of Santa Cruz to install both indoor and outdoor stoves for a family there. The children of this family are students of the Santa Cruz school, and Helps is implementing Home Transformation project focusing on families of students that has already provided 60 ONIL Water Purification Systems.
<blockquote><em><strong>"It has been a beautiful work, when you get the chance to  know 3 cultures. For me, it is beautiful to have this chance at a  relationship. Every volunteer that comes here has a big heart, and I am a  believer. I have seen the Lord."</strong></em>
<em><strong> - Mauricio Rosales</strong></em></blockquote>
With many years of experience under his belt, Mauricio is able to create for the volunteers an experience that adds great depth to the work they are doing. “It’s about the relationships with the people, talk with them about what we are doing.” HELPS understands the importance of the human dynamic on both sides of the equation and the connection that it creates between the volunteers and the recipients.

As the children run excitedly into the home, as if to make the way ready for the volunteers, Mauricio explains to the group the importance of the stove. As he talks to the woman of the house, he translates to the group that this woman has had an open fire in the home for over 30 years. In a home with so many children, the installation of the stoves will allow the family to make great strides towards a safer environment, by greatly reducing the risk of severe burns and eliminating the presence of toxic fumes.

Mauricio talks about the perspective he has gained from this experience. Working with both Guatemalans and U.S. volunteers and their efforts to create a brighter future for the people of his country.

<em>"It has been a beautiful work, when you get the chance to know 3 cultures. For me, it is beautiful to have this chance at a relationship. Every volunteer that comes here has a big heart, and I am a believer. I have seen the Lord."</em><em> - Mauricio Rosales</em>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>1881</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-05-09 19:29:29</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>mauricio-rosales</wp:post_name>

	<item>
				<title>Cammy Olsen</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2011/05/09/cammy-olsen/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2011 19:44:46 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=1891</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2011/05/09/cammy-olsen/attachment/cammyphoto5/" rel="attachment wp-att-1893"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-1893" title="CammyPhoto[5]" alt="" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/05/CammyPhoto5-300x172.jpg" width="300" height="172" /></a>

I was asked to write a short article on my experiences in Guatemala.  As I only work in the operating room and the patients are asleep, I don’t have a lot of stories that I can share about the patients as much as someone in clinic or recovery. What I can tell about are how the trips are coordinated and the impact on the volunteers.

The coordination begins almost after our leadership meeting on Memorial weekend.  Letters and applications are mailed out and by this time I’ve already had calls and emails about the upcoming year.  Volunteers are so anxious to know the next dates and locations that they have contacted me before I can get the information to them.  Many volunteers have told me that they look forward to this every year and it’s become a part of their lives.
<blockquote><strong>The impact on our Guatemalan friends is beyond words, but the impact these trips have on all of us that volunteer is even more profound.</strong></blockquote>
I’ve seen them laugh, cry and share stories with many of the patients.  I’ve heard the stories about how they have had to tell someone they can’t help; that they have to take that child home to die—how they want to be able to do more.  Stories about the little boy or girl who return for a second surgery to complete their care.  Stories of a child that can move their fingers after extensive hand surgery from burns.  So many of the patients become a part of their lives and they remember them year after year.

The impact on our Guatemalan friends is beyond words, but the impact these trips have on all of us that volunteer is even more profound.  We feel blessed that we have been able to participate in all parts of these missions.

-Cammy Olsen

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>5th Grade Field Trip</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/education/2011/05/27/5th-grade-field-trip/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 27 May 2011 20:55:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2050</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong> </strong>Watch the joy and discovery the 5th graders experience as they travel from a rural, highland Guatemala town to the big city!

<object classid="clsid:d27cdb6e-ae6d-11cf-96b8-444553540000" width="320" height="260" codebase="http://download.macromedia.com/pub/shockwave/cabs/flash/swflash.cab#version=6,0,40,0"><param name="src" value="http://blip.tv/play/AYGm3hsA" /><param name="allowfullscreen" value="true" /><embed type="application/x-shockwave-flash" width="320" height="260" src="http://blip.tv/play/AYGm3hsA" allowfullscreen="true"></embed></object>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>2050</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2011-05-27 12:55:16</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2011-05-27 20:55:16</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>5th-grade-field-trip</wp:post_name>

	<item>
				<title>A Special Surprise: Tony and Carol&#039;s Story</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2011/08/03/a-special-surprise-tony-and-carols-story/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Aug 2011 20:31:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[ernie.didot]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=2834</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="size-medium wp-image-2836 alignleft" style="margin: 3px;" title="Tony&amp;CarolPic1" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/TonyCarolPic1-300x199.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="199" />

<em>The following is an account from Tony and Carol while serving on HELPS Stove Teams.</em>

In June, 2007, I participated in my very first mission trip to Guatemala with Christ Church Plano members and HELPS International. We were assigned to work in Cipresales, and we stayed in Panajachel. It was a challenging trip, with long, difficult hikes between houses. When we arrived at the last house of the first day, the family did not have all of the supplies yet. They made multiple trips up and down the steep mountainside, bringing us the materials: huge bags of sand, cinderblocks, the cement cook top, etc. Three young boys would run down the mountain carrying cinderblocks, while their very pregnant mother helped carrying other materials. She disappeared while we were building the stoves. A brahma bull watched our every move from about 15 feet away. Chickens with their chicks following them were everywhere. As we were finishing up, we noticed the father running back and forth between the buildings. Then we heard the cry of a newborn baby. The pregnant woman had given birth to their fourth son while we were building their stoves! What an incredible experience! The husband asked us to wait a bit so we could pray with his wife and their newborn. About 45 minutes later, we were ushered into the tiny bedroom. We stood around the bed, holding hands, praying, and blessing the family, the new baby, and the stoves. Our team was blessed immeasurably that day.

<img class="size-medium wp-image-2837 alignleft" style="margin: 2px;" title="Tony&amp;CarolPic2" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/TonyCarolPic2-300x199.jpg" alt="" width="300" height="199" />This year, I completed my fifth Stove Building Mission Trip to Guatemala. My husband, Tony, and I have gone together for the past four years. Every year has been amazing, no two years the same, with some years easier than others, but God has blessed us on every trip, sharing His incredible creation with us, and keeping us safe.  It is more blessed to give than to receive, but when we leave Guatemala each year, our hearts are filled with love and gratitude. We are already looking forward to next year's trip.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>2013 Care Awards recognize AMN for work with HELPS</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2013/08/08/amn-selected-by-american-staffing-associal-for-asa-the-care-award-in-recognition-of-their-efforts-with-helps-international/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 08 Aug 2013 17:26:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=3229</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[The American Staffing Association (AMA) honors recipients of the 2013 Care Awards which recognize outstanding corporate social responsibility initiatives. Health care staffing company <a href="http://www.amnhealthcare.com/" target="_blank">AMN Healthcare</a> created its "AMN Community Connections" program, which provides charitable giving, scholarship programs, relief efforts, and team member volunteerism to support initiatives for the underserved, education, and economic development. Last April, a team of AMN doctors, nurses, and executives visited Guatemala to offer their medical services to hundreds of people in need. With assistance from the nonprofit organization HELPS, the team conducted nearly 94 surgeries, 100 dental treatments, and attended to 562 patients in need. (Team Esperanza)]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>A Tribute to Bill McConnell</title>
		<link>http://www.helpsintl.org/news/2014/01/03/memorial-bill-mcconnell/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Jan 2014 15:55:44 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Awalker]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.helpsintl.org/?p=4070</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<blockquote>
<p style="text-align: left;"><img class="size-medium wp-image-4102 alignright" alt="bill mcconnell pic" src="http://www.helpsintl.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/01/bill-mcconnell-pic-300x225.jpg" width="300" height="225" /><strong>Bill McConnell was a great friend, uncle, team leader, patriot, husband, father, extraordinary business man, a man of great integrity, a man of faith and someone who loved the Americas. </strong></p>
</blockquote>
<p style="text-align: left;">We lost Bill McConnell as 2013 was drawing to a close.  Bill was born in 1924 and lived most of his life in Jackson, Michigan.  He represented that great generation of World War II and trained pilots to fly most of the airplanes including the famous P-51.  He married Helen Watterson and they had four children, Bill Jr., Chris, Bob and Michelle. He was an engineer that worked most of his career for Aeroquip and Consumer Power.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Many of us met Bill and Helen through the HELPS Medical team experience.  After learning about HELPS and the medical teams, he and Helen volunteered on the Don and Lois O'Neal Dallas Medical Teams in the early 1990's. They worked in the kitchen as Helen is a master cook and baker. One can't forget her acres of pies and her dropping by at breakfast with another huge frosting laden cinnamon bun saying; "It's good for you! Just one more! You will need it today!"</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Bill met and became close to Don O'Neal's brother Dick and his wife Delores in those Nebaj kitchens.  Both men spoke the same "engineer" language and after their first trip they stayed on with the O'Neal's in Antigua to do a quality assurance analysis of the team kitchen.  Much of what we do and the system employed today in our kitchens and the overall team manual, came from these gentlemen.  Jon Christiansen still remembers the sighs behind him as he peeled potatoes, knowing that according to the schedule he was supposed to be finished 4 minutes earlier.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Bill and Helen then asked Lois O'Neal what she thought of them developing a Medical Team from Michigan.  Bill was retired by this time but as all the team leaders in our system, it took huge courage to step out and organize this effort. Bill had no hospital behind him and no real medical co-leader to rely on for recruitment.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">He did it anyway and pulled in the Weatherwax Foundation and others such as the current medical team leader Jack Wagoner.  He developed a strong cohesive team that has been in operation since 1996.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Bill continued until he could not physically make the trip. The year, before his last team, he suffered an aneurism while in Guatemala but was ready to go the next year.  He was the type of man that when he said "Yes", nothing could stop him from fulfilling those three letters.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Certainly with his other legacies, Bill's greatest contribution was his family and his impact in Guatemala will go on forever.  His twelve seasons has human and spiritual ripples that have cascaded through those highlands in ways that he is now discovering.</p>

<blockquote>
<p style="text-align: left;"><strong>I know we will miss him, his laugh, thoughtfulness, intellect, work ethic, humor, and effectiveness. Speaking as his nephew, I have been most blessed and proud to say that William McConnell was my Uncle.</strong></p>
</blockquote>
<p style="text-align: left;">God Bless you Bill.  You have joined my father, Dick O'Neal and other HELPS alumni for an effective, humor filled quality assurance meeting.</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">So in this New Year, may we celebrate Bill and his new life and ours.  May we resolve to live to his standards of life and may God bless us all in 2014."</p>
&nbsp;
<p style="text-align: left;">Sincerely,</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">Steve Miller</p>
<p style="text-align: left;">President, HELPS International</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
